commit_message:
adding hook for custom script

adding env var DEVSTACK_GATE_CUSTOM_SCRIPT. if set, then update-image.py
will upload the script specified and run it after all other
configuration and preparation is complete, just before taking a snapshot
of the image.

Change-Id: I319a8f8dc4fa1de642b467b4504dca64c5290a29

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 22:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Looks good overall.  I could use some information:

a) why the change from network, mapping to vif and passing as a tuple? It seems unintuitive

b) is network_info always a list of [vif] where vif == (network, mapping) ?  I thought i saw places in the code where network_info was a singular vif, but I could be imagining things

c) I want to give this some time to bake before pushing this in.

d) Are there more tests that could be added to verify the changes that you made are correct, or are the existing tests sufficient?"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-04-25 22:37:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

thanks vish, responses inline here

a) why the change from network, mapping to vif and passing as a tuple? It seems unintuitive

All of the virt vif modules inherit from the top level vif module, I chose to update the top level vif module to what it would look like when this is all finished, and a vif is passed in. To make things work for now, in the nonxenapi versions of vif, i expect vif to be the (network, info) tuple that the nonxenapi virts shove into the one vif variable so all levels of the vif driver use the same function parameters. It is a bit screwy, but it's just a shim for now. Eventually it will just be vif everywhere.


b) is network_info always a list of [vif] where vif == (network, mapping) ? I thought i saw places in the code where network_info was a singular vif, but I could be imagining things

Libvirt still uses the legacy network info, so what it has to pass to vif or firewall is going to be the list of (network, vif) tuples. All of the virts (besides xenapi after this point) will still use the list of tuples. In the network model you basically have a list of vifs with all of the related information underneath. Check out the model at nova/network/model.py for more info. The two versions exist now because all of virt isn't updated yet.

c) I want to give this some time to bake before pushing this in.

no problems with that on my end. What problem do you want to solve by waiting?

d) Are there more tests that could be added to verify the changes that you made are correct, or are the existing tests sufficient?

most all of this code is already covered by existing tests. I know because a lot of them broke in the process. If you notice anything that could use a specific test, I'm happy to write them.


One other thing I want to point out, this code allows using only ipv6 in xenapi."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-04-30 18:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is a great first step in converting everything away from the Networking Blob of Despair'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 19:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good to me.

Vish, how long did you want to let this bake?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-07 20:34:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

been long enough. Approved.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3912/ : SUCCESS

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3805/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-10 19:57:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Besides the merge conflict Jenkins points out... I would also mention this doesn't pass XenServer SmokeStack.

I haven't had a chance to take a look yet but I wanted to mention it..."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-11 21:25:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-11 21:47:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There's an introduced HACKING compliance issue in test_libvirt.py; dunno how I managed to miss it the first time around…"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-15 06:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Nothing about that list of imports looks "human alphabetical" to me. Normally I really don't care, but now that I've been inconvenienced by it, I'll bite.

how is http://pastie.org/3913662 more "human alphabetical" than http://pastie.org/3913666

Also, since I don't actually care, I've moved the imports (you didn't miss it, result of a merge).'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-15 06:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-15 16:08:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So, the first pastie you had was almost in the correct order, except for a few pieces.  The rule of thumb is to pretend that "from nova import utils" is actually "import nova.utils", then order based on that.  So, the correct ordering would be http://pastie.org/3915934 (and your mental image of this for ordering purposes would be http://pastie.org/3915950).'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-15 16:15:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
update xen to use network_model

blueprint xenapi-network-info-model

updated xenapi to use the new network info models

also:
updated virt firewall to handle both old version and new hotness
made a few minor changes to the network info model
moved the legacy converstion shim from compute/utils to the model itself
wharrgarbl'd a few of the tests

NOTE: no unittests were skipped during the creation of this patch

Change-Id: Ib77dd2bf4f0a525b73800441f19013e842c77f98

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-29 15:21:33.000000000', 'message': "cfg: add a global CONF object

Implements blueprint cfg-global-object

Add an instance of the CommonConfigOpts class to the cfg module's
global namespace.

The usage pattern is:

  from openstack.common import cfg

  opts = [
      cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='blaa'),
      cfg.StrOpt('bar', default='blaa'),
      ]

  CONF = cfg.CONF
  CONF.register_opts(opts)

  def do_something_later():
      print CONF.foo, CONF.bar

  def main():
      CONF(project='pulsar')

Change-Id: I77e87b1e186c243b2638a4b1c202f865249dafce
"}]
commit_message:
cfg: add a global CONF object

Implements blueprint cfg-global-object

Add an instance of the CommonConfigOpts class to the cfg module's
global namespace.

The usage pattern is:

  from openstack.common import cfg

  opts = [
      cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='blaa'),
      cfg.StrOpt('bar', default='blaa'),
      ]

  CONF = cfg.CONF
  CONF.register_opts(opts)

  def do_something_later():
      print CONF.foo, CONF.bar

  def main():
      CONF(project='pulsar')

Change-Id: I77e87b1e186c243b2638a4b1c202f865249dafce

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-29 15:12:14.000000000', 'message': "cfg: move constructor args to __call__() args

In order to effectively use a global ConfigOpts object, you
need to be able to initialize the global object with none of
the information we currently require at construction.

By moving those constructor args to the __call__() method,
we enable the global object usage model but also make the API
generally more flexible. For example, you can now reset the
object and re-use it for parsing a different set of config
files with the same options.

There are a couple of other minor behavior changes as a
result:

  - print_usage() and print_help() no longer works before
    the object has been called to parse options

  - registration of duplicate short options are no longer
    detected until the options are parsed

  - the --config-file and --config-dir options aren't
    registered until just before parsing the options since
    the default set of config files can be specified at
    that time

  - find_file() can't be used until after the options have
    been parsed, again because of the late registration
    of --config-file and --config-dir

Finally, an unregister_opt() method is added to support
the re-registeration of the --config-file and --config-dir
options.

Change-Id: I650d8e299e92cbc5d10da47a7ce1b73ca8066bd0
"}]
commit_message:
cfg: move constructor args to __call__() args

In order to effectively use a global ConfigOpts object, you
need to be able to initialize the global object with none of
the information we currently require at construction.

By moving those constructor args to the __call__() method,
we enable the global object usage model but also make the API
generally more flexible. For example, you can now reset the
object and re-use it for parsing a different set of config
files with the same options.

There are a couple of other minor behavior changes as a
result:

  - print_usage() and print_help() no longer works before
    the object has been called to parse options

  - registration of duplicate short options are no longer
    detected until the options are parsed

  - the --config-file and --config-dir options aren't
    registered until just before parsing the options since
    the default set of config files can be specified at
    that time

  - find_file() can't be used until after the options have
    been parsed, again because of the late registration
    of --config-file and --config-dir

Finally, an unregister_opt() method is added to support
the re-registeration of the --config-file and --config-dir
options.

Change-Id: I650d8e299e92cbc5d10da47a7ce1b73ca8066bd0

Thanks,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 4200, 'date': '2012-05-15 12:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

the bash-completion command is not supported and not needed. glance prints all possible commands, when an unknown command is issued. see http://pastebin.com/s0h2FWXH'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-15 15:01:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Dominik,

Would it make better sense to use an option like '-h' that's actually supported by *both* (a) the legacy CLI and (b) the new python-glanceclient?

(a) http://paste.openstack.org/show/17680/
(b) http://paste.openstack.org/show/17682/

(output would require some conditional parsing to account for the differences in format).

Note the legacy glance CLI is on the deprecation path and will be effectively replaced by python-glanceclient in Folsom.

Also, would it be useful to have access to the supported set of options (--os-username etc.) as well as the commands (index/image-list etc.) so that these are available via tab-completion also?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 4200, 'date': '2012-05-16 08:37:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4200, 'date': '2012-05-16 08:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

now works with both legacy CLI and python-glanceclient'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-16 13:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Dominik for taking the feedback on board.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-16 15:52:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Dominik,

Just one other point, that won't block this landing, but should be attended to before the next release.

I've just been discussing this with the Fedora openstack package maintainer, to ensure that your script is dropped into /etc/bash_completion.d as a side-effect of the Fedora openstack-glance package being installed.

Can you follow-up similarly on the Debian/Ubuntu packages?

Thanks,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-16 16:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This also needs to land in python-glanceclient. The client code in this repo will be extracted before Folsom is released.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-21 17:58:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-07 00:45:05.000000000', 'message': "Improve API logging.

See bug 975589.

Move logging to after running the request, to be able to capture response attributes. Separate out error logging into a separate channel. Add new log fields and remove spurious error logging.

Note that I haven't captured response length, as I wanted to make sure it wasn't being streamed (thereby needlessly buffering it).

Something to look at is whether the various textual log fields need appropriate escaping. Also, I use time.time() twice  to calculate latency; this is a sys call, but I see it used throughout the code elsewhere.

Also, apologies but this is untested; I'm currently on the road with a macbook, don't have a devstack environment handy.

Change-Id: Ia6df30db4aa5a356116b139a0c06bbb0f18c818f

commit_message:
Improve API logging.

See bug 975589.

Move logging to after running the request, to be able to capture response attributes. Separate out error logging into a separate channel. Add new log fields and remove spurious error logging.

Note that I haven't captured response length, as I wanted to make sure it wasn't being streamed (thereby needlessly buffering it).

Something to look at is whether the various textual log fields need appropriate escaping. Also, I use time.time() twice  to calculate latency; this is a sys call, but I see it used throughout the code elsewhere.

Also, apologies but this is untested; I'm currently on the road with a macbook, don't have a devstack environment handy.

Change-Id: Ia6df30db4aa5a356116b139a0c06bbb0f18c818f

commit_message:
fix some pylint warnings.

1. Parent class should have instance variables used in its method(s).
2. remove some unused imports
Patch 2: fix according to comments
Patch 4: fix problem under pep8 1.1
Change-Id: Iafd89a6017b30484fb8da50219be6b4ae073f083

commit_message:
Relax python webob and pam restrictions

Distros are shipping newer versions of python-webob
and hard coding webob to 1.0.8 will cause problems
for users going forward, at least on Ubuntu and Debian.

Change-Id: Ica066079c5c11011eab54510f9f58fa0dd460b35
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Replace eucatools with references to nova CLI

fixes bug 891552

It has been decided to prefer novaclient over euca2ools when novaclient
does the job, so this fix is to bring the compute manual to implement
the remaining changes to bring it to fuitition.

Most of the work here is in the volumes section. Essentialy hacked
away to replace euca-*-volume commands with nova volume-*.

Also removed some old volumes-related text that seemed irrelevant in
current releases.

Change-Id: I020f86d337527c38af719703909ad52ae35f2d7b

subject: _s3_create update only pertinent metadata
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 4277, 'name': 'John Tran', 'email': 'jhtran@att.com', 'username': 'jtran'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-23 22:02:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-24 12:21:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think this fix is quite incomplete

There are three classes of updates we're doing in s3_create() and we need to make sure we're only setting the image attrs we intended to set in each case

The first class of update is updating the image_state as we go through each stage. For this, we simply want to do:

  PUT /v1/images/<id>
  x-image-meta-property-image-state: downloading
  x-glance-registry-purge-props: false

The other classes are when we're uploading the image file or setting its status to 'active'. In these cases, if we just do:

  PUT /v1/images/<id>

  <image data>

and:

  PUT /v1/images/<id>
  x-image-meta-status: active

then I think we'll be ok because glance won't overwrite any image attributes.

So, I'd add these helper methods:

  def update_image_state(context, image_uuid, image_state):
      metadata = {'properties': {'image_state': image_state}}
      headers = {'x-glance-registry-purge-props': false}
      self.service.update(context, image_uuid, metadata, headers)

  def update_image_data(context, image_uuid, image_data):
      metadata = {}
      self.service.update(context, image_uuid, metadata, image_data)

  def update_image_status(context, image_uuid, status):
      metadata = {'status': status'}
      self.service.update(context, image_uuid, metadata, status)

However, a big problem is that the glance client doesn't allow you to pass headers to update_image(). See the glance xenapi plugin's updload_tarball() method for how it's using httplib directly to make a request which includes the x-glance-registry-purge-props header"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-24 16:43:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark, mostly you are correct :) However, the glance client update_image() method DOES allow you to specify the x-glance-registry-purge-props=False header. The Nova GlanceImageService.update() method needs to be updated to pass the features={'x-glance-registry-purge-props': False} keyword arg to the glance.client.Client.update_image() call.

See code in glance.client here:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/87e45ac659172a49c9ba281e65917d3892308321/glance/client.py#L164"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-24 16:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

See inline...'}, {'account_id': 1071, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-05-25 16:04:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sorry, I accidentally pushed this git review early, it's not ready yet gotta fix my test."}, {'account_id': 1071, 'date': '2012-05-25 19:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-25 20:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/4/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-25 20:39:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-05-26 03:29:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Mark: I didn't implement the update to 'active' image_state because when I attempted it glance api would return a 'Duplicate' exception.  It appears that glance API already updates the 'active' status upon image upload.  This occurs /glance/glance/api/v1/images.py Controller:
    def _activate(self, req, image_id, location):
        image_meta = {}
        image_meta['location'] = location
        image_meta['status'] = 'active'

        try:
            return registry.update_image_metadata(req.context,
                                                  image_id,
                                                  image_meta)"}, {'account_id': 1071, 'date': '2012-05-26 04:20:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-05-26 04:21:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I tested it again and couldn't reproduce the 'Duplicate' exception.
So I went ahead and incorporated the update status 'active' metadata."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-26 04:32:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/16/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/16/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/18/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/16/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-27 03:38:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

great find.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-28 08:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thanks John'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-28 09:59:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/224/ : SUCCESS

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-23 20:07:51.000000000', 'message': "Image create checks is_public metadata

Fixes bug 827458.  nova/image/s3.py _s3_create iterates through each status
during an image creation and doesn't check for new image metdata changes
such as is_public update pushed by cloud-publish-image -l all command.

commit_message:
_s3_create update only pertinent metadata

Fixes bug 827458.  nova/image/s3.py _s3_create iterates through each
image_state during image creation isn't mindful of metadata updates
such as 'is_public'.  Now will only update the specific pertinent
metadata instead of purging all.

Change-Id: I3e678d028464ac252383aa363baf488249dca198

I understand what they both do. I just wonder about all the code they

>> If I'm right, the change set I0291e19eee1ff2c5fc98b499571b2563841c6076

Both patch add nova/openstack/common/setup.py library, as they utilize methods from this library. Depending on which patch goes first, the other patch might fail to merge. IOW, Chuck/Monty or I should re-generate the patch after the other patch is merged."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-08 12:19:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is in pretty good shape IMHO, just a couple of things

First, a trivial thing - try "Fixes bug #976276" in the commit message. The bug report should automatically be updated with a link to this review and marked as "In Progress"

Second, there are a bunch of changes from the original Authors that need to be carefully reviewed: http://paste.openstack.org/show/16200/

I think you'll end up needing an AUTHORS.in file - e.g. I know William Henry was added because he co-authored the Qpid support in RPC, but Russell Bryant was the primary author'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-12 06:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-12 10:05:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Ok, AUTHORS.in need only contain:

 Alexander Kovalev <akovalev@mirantis.com>
 Ben Swartzlander <bswartz@netapp.com>
 Dong-In David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
 Tomoya Masuko <masukotm@nttdata.co.jp>
 William Henry <whenry@redhat.com>
 William Kelly <william.kelly@rackspace.com>
 Youcef Laribi <Youcef.Laribi@eu.citrix.com>
 Zhixue Wu <Zhixue.Wu@citrix.com>

We really should uniq base on email address:

 sed 's/.*<\(.*\)>/\1/' < AUTHORS | sort | uniq -c | sort -n

Can we filter out:

 Launchpad Translations on behalf of nova-core <>
 OpenStack Jenkins <jenkins@openstack.org>

Also filter out these, but the email address uniq-ing will probably do that anyway:

 root <masumotok@nttdata.co.jp>
 root <sleepsonthefloor@gmail.com>
 root <vishvananda@gmail.com>

Also seeing a bunch of '<>' e.g.

 -Brad McConnell <bmcconne@rackspace.com>
 +Brad McConnell bmcconne@rackspace.com <>"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-12 14:37:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Mark, thank you for detailed review comments. Few comments about it ...

1. As per limiting entries in AUTHORS.in file, there are few more authors not exist in git log, ex: Robert Esker <esker@netapp.com>. Why would you want to limit AUTHORS.in with just 8 entries? I generated AUTHORS.in programaably, to confirm we don't miss out any authors.

2. As per sorting AUTHORS.in, the reason I didn't sort is, in few projects, ex: swift, the AUTHORS.in contain headers, like "Contributors".
  https://raw.github.com/openstack/swift/master/AUTHORS
  
  Note, I'll post similar patch to auto generate AUTHORS for swift.

Can we include an header in AUTHORS.in file here, and not sort it along with git log output? Let me know your comments.

3. As per authors with name "root", can we fix git repository directly? We may not be able to sort, as email address is unique, anyway.

4. As per invalid chars like <>, is this something we could fix in git? There are also few entries like "paul@openstack.org <>". Fixing git repository, sounds like a optimal way to me.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-12 22:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

1. Rob Esker is in git-log, see I8e2781e8bd4a552354f46a32c4a7ecdfd19f3e7a - you should search based on people's email addresses

2. A header doesn't make sense Nova. What would it say? "People not listed in git-log". The content of AUTHORS should be fully sorted

3. No, we can't fix the git repository. Changing the author of a git commit changes the commit IDs of all subsequent commits. Just make sure the same email address isn't in AUTHORS twice

4. I think you're probably going to need to extend .mailmap to have entries like this:

  Paul Voccio <paul@openstack.org> paul@openstack.org <>'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-13 13:43:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

how about something like this:

  - get all authors listed in git-log
  - map all email addresses to preferred email using mailmap
  - uniq the entries so that each email address only 
    appears once - choose the latest fullname from git-log 
    associated with each email address
  - add in AUTHORS.in and again uniq based on email address
  - sort the output

That way we can use AUTHORS.in to fix any broken entries in git-log'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-15 17:54:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Mark, thank you detailed comments. In few instances, the name include both name and email addresses, and email address is blank:

barumuga@lexpad:~/projects/nova$ git log --format='%aN' | sort -u | grep '@'
Arvind Somya asomya@cisco.com
Brad McConnell bmcconne@rackspace.com
danwent@gmail.com
jaypipes@gmail.com
Joel Moore joelbm24@gmail.com
matt.dietz@rackspace.com
paul@openstack.org
Vivek YS vivek.ys@gmail.com

All these issues and the one you noted, like using latest full name, are solvable if we maintain right mapping in mailmap.

I'll include changes to .mailmap to address all these issues and also modify generate_authors() method to take optional argument, "sort_result". Use this argument, to sort the final AUTHORS, after adding AUTHORS.in'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-19 07:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-21 06:00:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There are still a lot of duplicate email addresses in the generated AUTHORS file and the contents of AUTHORS.in is appended rather than sorted

Also, changes to nova/openstack/common/setup.py need to be made in openstack-common first"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-28 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-28 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

  Remove this file. To be consistent with other projects,

  Include setup module to copy using update.py script.

  Import the new method.

* MANIFEST.in

.mailmap

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for nova.

Fixes Bug #976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

.mailmap
  Fix mailmap entries inline with actual author name and
  email address in git. For instance, for few commits, the
  name points to email address and email address is blank.
  Add right mapping for such inconsistency in git log.

* Authors
  Remove this file. To be consistent with other projects,
  the new file AUTHORS is generated automatically.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* nova/openstack/common/setup.py
  Add this library from openstack-common code base.

* openstack-common.conf
  Include setup module to copy using update.py script.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package. If
  sort_result=True, concatenate AUTHORS.in and sort the final
  result.

* nova/utils.py
  parse_mailmap(), str_dict_replace(): Remove these methods.

* nova/tests/test_misc.py
  ProjectTestCase.test_authors_up_to_date(): Remove this
  method.

* MANIFEST.in
  s/Authors/AUTHORS

* AUTHORS.in
  Include old authors, not listed in git log.

Change-Id: Id3cd8bffab2247ee62e321751ccf3fe2768d983c

commit_message:
clean-up of the bare-metal framework.

address minor problems and errors found in the driver, such as old
docstrings, unused imports, and variables, references of non-existent
classes, and methods; plus remove the requirement that every sub-driver
needs to be implemented as singleton, as the tilera one.

Change-Id: I5943bcdd785c1b4b83e95f88bd7d69c1edc5f62f

Hi Dan,

I just tried to setup the linuxbridge plugin using this script.
I see an error issued when a vm is created on the default network. It looks like it is creating the bridge interface for the default network before the first vm is created. So the vm creation on the default network fails

I checked with Sumit and he said he had seen a similar error while reviewing this patch.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7169/
So I am not sure if it is linked to your changes

Vms created on private networks seem to go through ok.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-15 18:14:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, from off-review conversation, it seems like this issue is independent of my change.  If so, shweta, can you review the rest of the patch? 

This is a pretty big change-set and I'm trying to get out of rebase hell :)"}, {'account_id': 1269, 'date': '2012-05-15 21:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Hi Dan,

I have tested this on a single node setup. Not been able to test it on multiple hosts. 

Other than a minor comment .. the code looks good to me. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-15 21:55:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

thx shweta.  reply inline.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-17 18:26:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi folks, what can I do to help get some core reviews on this?  

This change-set is a key Quantum goal for Folsom-1, as it lets people test multi-node topologies with quantum quite easily.  I've tested it extensively in my own setups.  

Currently, the review is just setting around and I keep getting killed by re-bases."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-05-17 20:41:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Dan, part of the problem here has been multiple patches on the same bit of code.  The other is that I can't test all of the permutations so I rely on folk closer to the project to do some of that and give a positive review.

And, guess what...it needs another rebase.  I promise, no more quantum changes to stack.sh until this one gets in!  ;)"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-05-18 04:42:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Dan for doing this. I have tested this with the Linux Bridge plugin on a single host, and things seem to be working fine.

There is a patch I have submitted for review which related to an issue in the LB interface driver, and which I had to use here to test this.

I see an issue with the VMs on the default public network not being able to reach the meta-data server. I have observed this even in the trunk and I don't believe it has anything to do with this patch."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:13:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:14:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, rebased again.  No functional changes since last set of reviews.  I've tested this on a multi-node setup."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:16:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

btw, thanks for the comments Dean.

One thing that will really help is getting Quantum into the commit gating, so we can be sure that changes to the devstack script do not break Quantum prior to those changes being merged.  We're definitely working on this, and hopefully it will make your life easier.  Devstack is a huge win for the Quantum team, so keeping it in good shape is a priority for us.  

Let me know how I can help out, and feel free to add me to Quantum-related devstack reviews."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:46:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
enable quantum multi-node scenarios.

Let's you run with a centralized quantum service node running the plugin
and quantum agents running on one or more hosts.

Also:
- make OVS plugin work on precise by configuring cgroup_device_acl
- consolidate ovs + linux-bridge config to avoid duplicate code
- support configuring tunnel-mode for OVS plugin
- add additional build packages for OVS apt-get
- remove backward compat support for old DB config for linux-bridge plugin

Change-Id: Ifab268f739b004db13024633e8abeb17691b9e46

commit_message:
Added an AddImageException to exceptions.py and modified images_client to use this exception rather than BuildErrorException.

Fixes bug 999256.

exceptions.py:
class AddImageException(TempestException):
    message = "Image %(image_id) failed to become ACTIVE in the allotted time."

images_client.py:
In wait_for_image_resp_code and wait_for_image_status, changed:

  raise exceptions.BuildErrorException

to:

  raise exceptions.TimeoutException

In wait_for_image_status, changed:

  raise exceptions.BuildErrorExcption

to:

  raise exceptions.AddImageException(image_id=image_id)

Replaced TimeoutException with AddImageException and replaced AddImageException with TimeoutException.

Change-Id: Ic78f1d24151361c9886480822087931b61b3603c

subject: Fix pep8 errors
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-merge/5/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-pep8/5/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python26/5/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python27/5/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We should always use the latest version of pep8 the package because it is becoming more inline with PEP8. The goal is to be PEP8 compliant, not just pass the checks that the pep8 package has implemented.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'll abandon this, gongysh included the fixes in the pylint fix branch. The problem with pegging at all is no one will ever update it (0.7 came out in March)."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Requiring 0.6.1 is fine. I just thought the idea was to make sure the project was PEP8 compliant, not just pass the tests that the pep8 module implements.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This issues are popping up as the CI infrastructure seems to have switched to using 1.1 all of a sudden.  I'm working with monty on this.  I'd prefer not to change tools/test-requires to allow arbitrary versions of pep8, as this allows developers to be out of sync with each other and out of sync with Jenkins.  I'd prefer that we either agree to stick on 0.6.1 or agree to all move to 1.1 .  

Based on monty's input, I'm pushing a change to tox.ini that should enforce 0.6.1 for now.  

I'm of course fine with the actual code style changes either way, my only concern is with the change to test-requires."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm fine with using the latest pep8, as long as everyone is consistently using that version.

So how about you want to take this patch, update to use 1.1 in both test-require and tox.ini, and include the style fixes? 

What I don't like about just specifying "pep8" alone in test-requires is that ANY version of pep8 will satisfy this, even if the person is not up to date.  I've seen this before and it results in confusion as people are running different versions.  When a new version comes out, we can just tweak these files.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

My understanding is that the CI folks periodically poked the projects to update, but that may no longer be true.  

I'm fine is you push a separate change-set doing whatever you'd prefer to do on this one in terms of hard-coding pep8 versions if you feel strongly about it."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-26 07:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Knox in box'}]

Fix pep8 errors

gongysh: Some of your suggestions have merit, but are out of scope.  The intent of this change is a refactor to make the code python2.4 compatible, not change how logging is performed.  Optimizing how database errors are logged seems a bit pointless given that the pending rewrite will remove (or at least significantly modify) database communication."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-26 06:51:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Hi,
Besides the comments inline, I found we can remove all the Exception variable reference totally in this file ( including other ideas):
1. There is no need for LOG.info to use Exception variable. The meaningful msg is enough.
2. If we want more debug information, we can add one more statement LOG.debug('',exc_info=1) to print the traceback
3. If we need to exit program because of something, we had better use LOG.fatal(..) instead of LOG.error(...)
4. most of the LOG.info(...) seemingly should be replace with LOG.warning(...) see http://docs.python.org/howto/logging.html#logging-basic-tutorial

These are just my thoughts.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 4214, 'date': '2012-05-26 06:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-26 06:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

commit_message:
Bug #994831

Fix minor pep8 nits.

Output of the test suite rendered no errors:

run_tests.sh -p -l
Running pep8 ...

Fix minor nits on exceptions. Change log.fatal to log.critical in line 711

Change-Id: I95d341ba132eb82696847620d5568faf80e0d938

commit_message:
Remove deprecated nova-manage commands

* Remove nova-manage account *
* Remove nova-manage export *
* Remove nova-manage project *
* Remove nova-manage role *
* Remove nova-manage user *
* Remove nova-manage shell export
* Remove relevant tests
* Partially implements bp remove-deprecated-auth

Change-Id: I18631a0222c3a2a2983c65a80218743cf672b969

commit_message:
Added support for proper bare URLs.

If we want to use github zipballs as a source of depends sometimes
(which we do) - we need to have the pip-requires parsing understand
that lines starting with http:// or https:// are urls and should go
to dependency_links.

Change-Id: I9218159872d6edfebd4b820e6db912e9aabdf7d7

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python27/1/ : SUCCESS"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-25 22:25:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ok, I was confused about how there could be pep8 issues with that fix.  Turns out they aren't in this patch, but it seems like jenkins upgraded to pep8 version 1.1, which flags some new issues.  

Do you want to fix those in a separate branch, then, submit that branch first?  I'd file a separate bug on this.  

Suggestion about fixing the commit message for this patch still holds though."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-25 22:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Good catch on this one Aaron.  Thanks for the fix.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-25 22:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

whoops, actually, two things:

commit_message:
Bug #1004584

When running ovs_quantum_agent in tunneling mode and a new tunnel_ip is added while
an agent is running the following exception below occurs. This causes the agent to
no longer function since it becomes caught in a loop.

ERROR:__main__:Main-loop Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 583, in daemon_loop
    self.manage_tunnels(tunnel_ips, old_tunnel_ips, db)
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 550, in manage_tunnels
    self.add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan(lv_obj)
AttributeError: 'OVSQuantumTunnelAgent' object has no attribute 'add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan'

Change-Id: I39ca50dc13c6ce714fe856d5d3cb359ff8d93edf

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-23 19:10:17.000000000', 'message': 'Replace PUT with PATCH for image update in v2 API

Since we want to support partial image updates, we should be doing it
using the PATCH HTTP verb rather than PUT.

* Related to bp api-2

Change-Id: I70731e929daa063014b1a4c6e4a3ae2735b4e783
'}]
commit_message:
Replace PUT with PATCH for image update in v2 API

Since we want to support partial image updates, we should be doing it
using the PATCH HTTP verb rather than PUT.

* Related to bp api-2

Change-Id: I70731e929daa063014b1a4c6e4a3ae2735b4e783

commit_message:
Fix XenServer diagnostics to provide correct details

XenServer driver was providing the values which were
not the actual latest information, this makes sure the
information is the latest and fixes LP Bug #1002497

Change-Id: I4241be4a040fbadd630ba3c2cfaacbcf1c18f72e

commit_message:
Expose a limited networks API for users

Currently, users do not have any way of knowing what networks
are available for use, and in some scenarios such as when a
user wants to add a fixed IP, they do not have access to the
network ID.

This exposes a limited amount of information through the
existing networks extension for users and fixes LP Bug #1003979

Change-Id: I14cc3a377ee0f031b4edaf7eeec3a6550a402b1a

subject: Fix setup.py for non http(s) URLs
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I now believe this to be completely the wrong approach.

We have a workaround for our current issue in the form of github automatic zipfiles and https urls. Next step is actually just fixing dependency_links support in distribute upstream - because the difference in behavior between pip and distribute is MADDENING"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

How about we just print an error and exit if we hit a non-http URL? Shouldn't be be updating all URLs in projects' pip-requires to be http?

Monty's commit message in Iaded7245cea7a30c2f421c7b48ece9823aaf152f had a small bit more info:

  Pip knows how to handle git urls. distribute does not - 
  so we should not hand git urls to setup.py.

I think it's worth updating the commit message to include the info that it's distribute that has the problem. Even this is being fairly sparse on details, though."}, {'account_id': 2325, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Wait, -f means file?  ok, this will break things"}, {'account_id': 2325, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

nevermind my last comment, it is good'}, {'account_id': 2325, 'date': '2012-05-25 15:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Did this differently'}]

Change-Id: Ic2dc992c2c8a800f902bc9554fb242ee471db282
"}]
commit_message:
Fix setup.py for non http(s) URLs

Don't parse things like git URLs because they fail

Change-Id: Ic2dc992c2c8a800f902bc9554fb242ee471db282

commit_message:
Aligns prettytable output to the left

A recent release of prettytable has forced output to be
centered and the 'aligns' method no longer exists.
This fix should justify output of lists/dicts to the left again.

Change-Id: Icb2b353030ce384186daa3886e1580f59f19efd8

subject: Fixes bug 903875 – New tests for Volume Attachments
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-03 18:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

Looking good Rajalakshmi! Just a couple nits inline.

Also, could you please rename VolumesAttachmentsClient to VolumeAttachmentsClient?

Thanks!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-04-05 13:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-04-05 14:06:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-16 06:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I have the tests running and passing, just need to do a bit more review on the tests'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-17 05:50:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(2 inline comments)

Looks good. We need to be careful about readability of code. See the attached comments for future reference.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-27 19:32:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Let's get this in. We should clean up those magic numbers later..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 19:33:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-pep8/124/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-merge/164/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-05-04 18:02:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have some problems with the device list methodology. 

1. You are assuming that the device letters in your list are not already there. But, for example, in the ubuntu cloud image there is already a /dev/vda when booted. This test will fail if 'a' is in the random selection.

2. If the test fails, as in this case, the finally will get an out-of-range index error from the incomplete attachment ids list.

3. I am not sure why this test wants to be randomized on the drive letters. Seems like another source of possible test flakiness with no benefit."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-12 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-12 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-05-18 04:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Restored

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-18 18:25:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Rajalakshmi, did you have any responses to David's comments on the review?

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-05-24 07:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Jay,

David's concern about "device list methodology" seems to be correct. In order to check if device is already present on an instance, we need to ssh into the booted instance and check.

I have been facing problems on what user name and password should be used to do an ssh.Also sent mail to Daryl seeking for help.

Regards,
Rajalakshmi'}, {'account_id': 1795, 'date': '2012-05-24 17:25:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Please abandon this for now. We will pick up later once we have solution'}, {'account_id': 2238, 'date': '2012-05-25 05:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

Abandoning this for now. We will pick up later once we have solution.'}]

[{'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-05-14 23:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

had a bunch of merge conflicts to resolve so thought it was a good idea to start clean (especially since i got my local branch in a funky state after the rebase).'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-15 16:36:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just to get things started (I haven't finished reviewing yet by any means):

bin/swift-recon:642:9: E303 too many blank lines (2)

Averages are wrong; they used to be sum(reported_thingies) / float(count_reported) and now it's just count_reported / count_attempted.

replication_check doesn't check the reported > 0 from _get_stats causing blow ups.

Dunno if it matters, but the letter casing and wording on the reports is pretty inconsistent. Sometimes lowercase, sometimes titlecase, sometimes lowercase with underscores, etc. Sometimes descriptive, sometimes needing contextual guessing. Output like "[failure] - Unavailable" just looks weird to me. Not sure exactly what to do here, just raising the issue as an oddity.

'reported' is often displayed to three decimal places when it will always be an integer.

The admin_guide.rst has 'account_recon = account' instead of 'true' like the others. Also "pending's" can lose the apostrophe.

The reaper gets no love? (joking, not sure what you'd report there anyway).'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-05-15 19:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-05-15 20:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-05-15 20:16:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Expand recon middleware support

Expand recon middleware to include support for account and container
servers in addition to the existing object servers. Also add support
for retrieving recent information from auditors, replicators, and
updaters. In the case of certain checks (such as container auditors)
the stats returned are only for the most recent path processed.

The middleware has also been refactored and should now also handle
errors better in cases where stats are unavailable.

While new check's have been added the output from pre-existing
check's has not changed. This should allow existing 3rd party
utilities such as the Swift ZenPack to continue to function.

Change-Id: Ib9893a77b9b8a2f03179f2a73639bc4a6e264df7

issues with the NFS configuration that would cause it to fail if

documentation in preference for copy & pasting sections on generic
systems administration tasks (i.e. configuring NFS).

so there could well be issues remaining. However, I feel that this is
an improvement enough (it has a chance of working!) to check it in.

commit_message:
Updates live migration doc to work with nova user

Fixes bug 887358
Update to Live Migration section of the compute manual to address
issues with the NFS configuration that would cause it to fail if
used with Diablo or Essex.

Where possible I have tried to refer readers to the excellent Ubuntu
documentation in preference for copy & pasting sections on generic
systems administration tasks (i.e. configuring NFS).

I have only tested this doc on a similar, but not identical setup,
so there could well be issues remaining. However, I feel that this is
an improvement enough (it has a chance of working!) to check it in.
Your feedback most welcome.

Fixes bug 891082
By linking to the existing GlusterFS document that can be used in
place of NFS

Change-Id: If076bf9103d71e584bdffc026741947f133fa381

commit_message:
Fix integration of image properties in v2 API

The (de)serialization of images in the v2 API expected a db-like
properties list in some cases, while in others a flat dictionary. This
patch aligns the code by ensuring the properties dictionaries are
normalized before being passed in and out of the controller.

* Expands the images functional test case to cover this integration point
* Cast all images to dictionaries before returning from the controller
* Related to bp api-2

Change-Id: I8b09677f622151330630fc7b0267f0549bb1a458

"}]
commit_message:
Leave behind sqlite DB for red functional tests.

We leave behind the sqlite DB for failing tests to aid in diagnosis,
as the file size is relatively small and won't interfere with subsequent
tests, as it's in a per-test directory (which is blown-away if the test
is green).

Change-Id: I90be433fc6f02234b1118a547ea0b5524238161d

subject: add queue name argument to TopicConsumer
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 159, 'name': 'Eric Windisch', 'email': 'ewindisch@docker.com', 'username': 'ewindisch'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 595, 'name': 'Nick Barcet', 'email': 'nicolas@barcet.com', 'username': 'nijaba'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}, {'_account_id': 2064, 'name': 'Loic Dachary', 'email': 'loic@dachary.org', 'username': 'dachary'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:36:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

While this doesn't leak outside the AMQP drivers, I think the ceilometer project should be building against the RPC *abstraction* and not tying itself to specific implementations. For that reason, I'm inclined to block something that exists only for abusing the model.

About Monday or so, I'll be submitting for review, a fundamental implementation of the matchmaker blueprint which I hope will provide more transparency to exchanges/bindings within Nova and might eliminate the need for this longer-term."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:36:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(marking a clear -1)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 21:49:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't understand the nature of your objection. We are trying to use the RPC layer, but it seems we have uncovered a case not handled there already. This case may be unique to the notifications topics, since they are the sorts of messages that multiple listeners might want to receive.

Presumably other RPC drivers (ZeroMQ?) would need to implement this change, too. I modified the two actual drivers I found. The base Connection class doesn't declare any of the useful API methods, and neither does impl_fake.py, so I didn't make any changes there to reflect a change to the API."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:06:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I like this. We can revisit after the thing on Monday, but in the mean time it doesn't exist yet. Once it does this can be reverted, or I can just take the +2 away."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

patchset 3 fixes the pep 8 issue'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:19:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I wouldn't hold this back if it was using the abstraction layer, but it is not. The abstraction supplies Connection.create_consumer. TopicConsumer and FanoutConsumer are implementation-specific classes and should NOT be used directly by your applications. My -1 on this is not because this change itself is bad, but because it is being done in the wrong place, for the wrong reasons."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:22:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Are you saying I need to bring the change up to the level of Connection.create_consumer(), too?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:35:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Yes. ceilometer should call create_consumer(), not TopicConsumer(). If you need this functionality, it will need to be exposed in create_consumer.

That said, I'm happy with the arguments as they are now for create_consumer. I'm more than a bit concerned this would bring the abstraction a bit too low-level. I'd probably still -1 it, unless I heard some really compelling arguments. I'm not sure how I would support this argument in the ZeroMQ driver, besides ignoring it, or changing the behavior significantly.

Regardless, it seems that you can't use this code in earnest until the rpc stack moves into OpenStack common, or you can use your branch locally until we can agree on a solution."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:36:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ah, I think I understand what you mean. The methods in the impl_* modules, although named in a way to imply they are public, are in fact meant to be private. So instead of calling declare_topic_consumer(), I should be using create_consumer(). That still doesn't do what we need because we don't want all ceilometer clients to receive all messages (as it would with fanout=True). I can easily add the queue_name argument there, too. Perhaps it would be better to add another API method to Connection (with a name like create_worker) for this case?"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:38:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The idea of adding an add_worker/create_worker method seems reasonable. This would seem to couple nicely with my proposed exchange/bindings abstraction as well.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:42:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sounds good. I will work on that Monday and watch for your changes then, too.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-19 00:56:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Eric's point that we need to find a way to do this through the part of the rpc API intended to be public.  I certainly want to find a good way to do what you need, though."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The updated patch adds a create_worker() method to the public API defined in the Connection class.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-05-21 16:04:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

In addition to the new feature, thanks for adding the missing docstring markup!'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-22 15:41:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

See https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg12098.html for some more details on this change.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:57:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think I'm satisfied with this now, but we should have a sufficient exception if we cannot create_worker or create_consumer, and documentation on this.

Perhaps just create a CreateConsumerError and document that failure in an implementation should raise this?

Your choice as to whether it is necessary for amqp.py:create_worker to try/except:raise this exception (but probably a good idea)."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-05-23 09:06:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-23 12:01:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The underlying implementation of create_worker() calls the same code that create_consumer() does, and that code handles the exceptions. I didn't think the new method warranted a new exception type, since the result is still a consumer, just one that is configured differently.

I will have to look through the documentation to see what we have on RPC beyond the API stuff, which should come out of the build for free."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:00:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Doug: the caller might currently expect a generic RPCException, which isn't particularly clear.

This is specifically related to our discussion of that create_worker may not work with all (future) implementations. Yes, create_consumer should raise the same exception. My comment is part that create_consumer doesn't necessarily do the preferable thing currently, and that create_worker *should*. If we improve create_consumer in the process, all the better."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:01:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

I will remove my -1 though, because we can fix this in a patch if there aren't any other objections."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:41:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yes, I think it would make more sense to discuss the error handling cases on the mailing list and fix them in another patch. I'll be happy to work on that with you."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:42:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Changing to +1, on account that we'll address the exception later."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-23 20:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
add queue name argument to TopicConsumer

ceilometer is going to want to subscribe several worker processes
to the notifications.info topic queue. The pool of workers needs
to be assured of receiving all messages, without interference from
other clients listening for notifications. The TopicConsumer
class always assumes the topic and queue name should be the same,
but in the ceilometer case we want to use a separate named queue
with a different name. The only parameter that cannot be
controlled by the user of TopicConsumer is the queue name,
so this change adds the ability to set the queue name.

Change-Id: I41a525de2fd855ca30c24fafcfbfefd6ab615dd7

commit_message:
Fixes Bug 1004138 - Fix for Bug 992275 Breaks on Python < 2.7.

This is the offending code:

import unittest2 as unittest
from unittest.case import SkipTest

The fix is:

remove the import line
change the "from" line to:

from unittest2.case import SkipTest

Change-Id: I321eb401da8dec6c2732f3913af611bf78f684f5

commit_message:
Remove deprecated quota code.

This completes blueprint quota-refactor by removing the now-unused
classic quotas code.

This change is fairly substantial.  To make it easier to review, it has been
broken up into 3 parts.  This is the third part.

Change-Id: I8856f84655ef2e6d61b3d1f52190b83a96c87fdb

commit_message:
Use memcache to store consoleauth tokens

 * Rather than store tokens in a dict, use memorycache
   so that deployers can optionally use memcached if they
   would like to run multile nova-consoleauth processes
 * Fixes bug 989337

Change-Id: I96ec4d796e53b69a494d856269e3c4e8f9b3d222

(1 inline comment)

Hm, I don't really like the db update calls being replaced with calls to notification module (see more inline).  I wonder if we want a DB API call that is something like:  old_data, new_data = instance_update_and_give_me_original_info().

You could replace the DB update calls with those and then make explicit separate calls to the notifier.  Not sure I really like that, either, but. :)

Guess I'm curious about other people's opinions.

Also: I wonder if the notification module code should go into nova/notifier/api.py."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-05-17 20:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-17 21:35:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

The notification in the create db record call feels oddly-placed to me.

Overall though, seems fine. Would just like your feedback on the comments first."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-05-23 19:21:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-23 20:02:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I guess I do think it's a little wonky, but I'd prefer to leave it for now due to that call being called from potentially 2 different places right now (API and scheduler).

commit_message:
Added a instance state update notification

Added a instance update notification (compute.instance.update) that
will report on changes to vm_state and task_state. The goal here is
to provide useful insight into instance state transitions.  (e.g.
BUILDING->ACTIVE)

The new notification has minimial dependencies and is intended for
wide use across the different layers/packages within nova.  Calls
in compute api/manager, scheduler, and the virt layer that modify
the instance state have been instrumented with this notification.

Change-Id: I223eb7eccc8aa079b782f6bb17727cd0b71d18ed

subject: KVM and QEMU details
messages:
[{'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-22 04:51:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-05-23 11:21:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hey Lorin,
I've a couple observations, Qemu is presented as the poor alternative. What about explaining KMV is a fork of it, while both have the same functionalities? But try to remain OPS focused.
Also does presenting the feature matter ? (snapshot, convert,etc... ) ?
Razique"}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-05-23 17:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Razique:  Is there any reason to ever prefer QEMU over KVM if the KVM hardware support is there? I understand we should generally not be biased in favor of any particular technology, but I also think we should provide some basic advice to people who are starting out.  

Also, as far as I understand, QEMU and KVM are identical in terms of OpenStack features that are supported. 

I would like to pull the hypervisor support matrix into the docs at some point to describe which features are supported by each hypervisor.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-24 00:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think it's well known and acknowledged the KVMs performance is superior to QEMU - it's not a contested value judgement, but more a statement of fact.

As one of the leading OpenStack design tenets is 'scalability', I believe it's in line to mention that if you have KVM hardware support, you want to use it over QEMU.

You can see examples of how another project does it: eg https://help.ubuntu.com/community/KVM/Installation

"You can still run virtual machines, but it'll be much slower without the KVM extensions."

I think any feature comparison is valid, but not necessarily a history lesson ;)'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-05-24 07:32:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This I do not contest :-)
Though I  was only thinking about the fact when you run installations into VMs, KVM won't  work, QEMU will, as for the rest, I totally agree ;)"}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-24 11:34:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Understood - that's completely fair. Everyone should be able to make the choice to have VMs in their VMs so they can have VMs in their VMs ;)"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-05-24 18:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-24 18:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-manuals-merge/432/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-24 18:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-24 15:06:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix multi-host deployments using RabbitMQ

Currently the rabbit password and rabbit_host are no longer
written into nova.conf. This is due to this change:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6501/

My solution is to write the values if:
- they are set
- and you are not using the alternative queue system

Change-Id: I8de7b57125d1fdf50044fc2b3ae4683ac15d5a61
'}]
commit_message:
Fix multi-host deployments using RabbitMQ

Currently the rabbit password and rabbit_host are no longer
written into nova.conf. This is due to this change:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6501/

My solution is to write the values if:
- they are set
- and you are not using the alternative queue system

Change-Id: I8de7b57125d1fdf50044fc2b3ae4683ac15d5a61

commit_message:
Make it easier to develop devstack-gate.

Added SKIP_DEVSTACK_GATE_JENKINS=1 env variable to omit modifying
Jenkins when developing the devstack-gate scripts themselves.

Updated the docs to match recent changes.

Change-Id: I0f2fdc131f263ecb513a960b4e6e8a4cca2fdb77

commit_message:
Correct format of schema-image.json.

Correct the JSON format of schema-image.json. Fixes issues where
glance-api won't start due to invalid JSON in this file.

Fixes LP Bug #1003470.

Change-Id: Ibacc49f2c45e233bd6ad25b3334e013acaae8339

commit_message:
Adds sql_ config settings to glance-api.conf.

The Glance v2 API makes use of the DB directly. As such
we should include the sql_ configs in the default glance-api.conf
file.

Fixes LP Bug #1003504.

Change-Id: I5e287dafcd65864f56789ae22bab3dcc6b353a47

[{'created': '2012-05-24 03:09:08.000000000', 'message': 'API users should not see deleted flavors.

which allows deleted flavors (instance types) to be displayed via the flavors

Change-Id: I8236a2ca2a7b461a66c1118e599d5e49f2b650d8

commit_message:
API users should not see deleted flavors.

Reverts a change earlier today to instance_types.get_instance_type_by_flavor_id
which allows deleted flavors (instance types) to be displayed via the flavors
API.

Fixes LP Bug #1003741.

Change-Id: I8236a2ca2a7b461a66c1118e599d5e49f2b650d8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-22 00:50:33.000000000', 'message': "!! Changed db_preallocation to False

Long explanation, but hopefully answers any questions.

We don't like changing the default behavior of Swift unless there's a
really good reason and, up until now, I've tried doing this with this
new db_preallocation setting.

For clusters with dedicated account/container servers that usually
have fewer disks overall but SSD for speed, having db_preallocation
on will gobble up disk space quite quickly and the fragmentation it's
designed to fight isn't that big a speed impact to SSDs anyway.

For clusters with account/container servers spread across all servers
along with object servers usually having standard disks for cost,
having db_preallocation off will cause very fragmented database files
impacting speed, sometimes dramatically.

Weighing these two negatives, it seems the second is the lesser evil.
The first can cause disks to fill up and disable the cluster. The
second will cause performance degradation, but the cluster will still
function.

Furthermore, if just one piece of code that touches all databases
runs with db_preallocation on, it's effectively on for the whole
cluster. We discovered this most recently when we finally configured
everything within the Swift codebase to have db_preallocation off,
only to find out Slogging didn't know about the new setting and so
ran with it on and starting filling up SSDs.

So that's why I'm proposing this change to the default behavior.

We will definitely need to post a prominent notice of this change
with the next release.

Change-Id: I48a43439264cff5d03c14ec8787f718ee44e78ea
"}]
commit_message:
!! Changed db_preallocation to False

Long explanation, but hopefully answers any questions.

We don't like changing the default behavior of Swift unless there's a
really good reason and, up until now, I've tried doing this with this
new db_preallocation setting.

For clusters with dedicated account/container servers that usually
have fewer disks overall but SSD for speed, having db_preallocation
on will gobble up disk space quite quickly and the fragmentation it's
designed to fight isn't that big a speed impact to SSDs anyway.

For clusters with account/container servers spread across all servers
along with object servers usually having standard disks for cost,
having db_preallocation off will cause very fragmented database files
impacting speed, sometimes dramatically.

Weighing these two negatives, it seems the second is the lesser evil.
The first can cause disks to fill up and disable the cluster. The
second will cause performance degradation, but the cluster will still
function.

Furthermore, if just one piece of code that touches all databases
runs with db_preallocation on, it's effectively on for the whole
cluster. We discovered this most recently when we finally configured
everything within the Swift codebase to have db_preallocation off,
only to find out Slogging didn't know about the new setting and so
ran with it on and starting filling up SSDs.

So that's why I'm proposing this change to the default behavior.

We will definitely need to post a prominent notice of this change
with the next release.

Change-Id: I48a43439264cff5d03c14ec8787f718ee44e78ea

commit_message:
Replace git url with github zipball.

distribute does not grok git urls, but auto-generated zipfiles are a
short-term workaround until we've got pypi uploads sorted.

Fixes bug 1003328

Change-Id: Iaded7245cea7a30c2f421c7b48ece9823aaf152f

subject: Fix db migration 12
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-21 09:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Someone needs to explain how this is a user-visible bug - with the information in the bug report, I can't decide whether this meets the "high-impact user visible bug" criteria

The bug report makes it sound like if you create an image with no properties or members, you'll hit this issue

But the foreign_keys list represents all the foreign keys in the *schema*, not the foreign keys in a particular row'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:48:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

After some testing I couldn't find a test case that make it fail. Upgraded from 11 to 12 revision, 7 (table images_members was introduced in revision 8) to 12 and some others (with and without images properties) with no luck. This looks to be a residual case, so ignoring it.

As Mark pointed, the foreign_keys list points to the fk in the *schema*, so I guess this bug might came from a sqlite database with foreign keys constraints disabled."}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:54:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is my fault. I initially misread the code. 
This caused an issue for us as we hadn't set up migrations properly in our glance DB (using mysql) as the tables were created automatically (that bug has been fixed) and our DB didn't have any foreign keys."}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Anyway, it's safe code, but it managed to land in master :/"}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-05-24 08:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Ghe

It seems that there is agreement that this branch should be dropped, if this is the case, can you mark it Abandoned please.

Thanks :)'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-24 08:55:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

The get_disks() method is not used anywhere yet, and is not tested properly,
but it does not work as reported in bug #998089.

This patch add unit test for it and fixes it so it's now possible to
retrieve the list of device name associated with a libvirt domain.

Change-Id: If09fb683364174fe02cbcbec4c6bbcda991287d6
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix libvirt Connection.get_disks method

The get_disks() method is not used anywhere yet, and is not tested properly,
but it does not work as reported in bug #998089.

This patch add unit test for it and fixes it so it's now possible to
retrieve the list of device name associated with a libvirt domain.

Change-Id: If09fb683364174fe02cbcbec4c6bbcda991287d6
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>
