commit_message:
Introduced _atomic_restart_dhcp() Fixes Bug 977875

Introduced a new method which executes update_dhcp_text_file
and restart_dhcp as one atomic unit - to avoid race between these
steps.

Change-Id: I6fda9fbfcaf59fa6a4859b361574d98e16331882

commit_message:
Logged an error statement into the syslog.

Fixes bug 925630

Logged an error into the syslog if the
user other than root trying to
start keystone service though not having
permissions to access keystone.conf file.

Change-Id: I515aa2b4256cc4f8aa0194cd43d66a9d0852155c

commit_message:
Friendly error message for untrusted CA certificates

novaclient currently returns "ERROR: n/a (HTTP 400)" for untrusted SSL CA
certificates and this commit makes the message a little friendlier.

Also updated the comments in from_response() to match the current code.

Change-Id: I34b1e71116a682cc3f020f7fb333c997ca7814d9

commit_message:
More accurate rescue mode testing for XenAPI

Update test_rescue to make sure the swap partition wasn't rescued. Since
this test fails with the current code, I also updated the code so the test
passed.

Fixes bug 997835

Change-Id: I9f09b3bbbee0ddfcbfdb243a7dff0b9bae99925d

Node JS is a Horizon requirement now.

Horizon is going to start using LessCSS, so Node
JS needs to be installed now with Horizon now.

commit_message:
Adds sql_ config settings to glance-api.conf.

The Glance v2 API makes use of the DB directly. As such
we should include the sql_ configs in the default glance-api.conf
file.

Fixes LP Bug #1003504.

Change-Id: I5e287dafcd65864f56789ae22bab3dcc6b353a47

commit_message:
Sync with latest version of openstack.common.cfg

Changes since last sync:

 - Alphabetize imports in openstack/common/cfg.py
 - make reset() clear defaults and overrides
 - automatically create option groups
 - allow options to be marked as required
 - use a list comprehension instead of map()

Change-Id: I74fac3f66b37ee07bab53bd655c0297f25849979

commit_message:
Fail gracefully if paste config file is missing.

If the paste config file can't be found, fail with a RuntimeError
and message instead of a traceback from os.path.abspath.

Change-Id: Id8823dbadab06a0de6bb7c235b70c355812ed55e

Can you open a bug report that shows the failure that occurs without this patch and then update the commit message to reference the bug?"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-05-14 16:18:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-18 15:07:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Yun,

Can you paste the traceback you get when this test fails? I'm a bit confused because the only place where obj.__unicode__ would be called is from the builtin python function unicode(obj). And the docs claim that unicode() will test for the existence of obj.__unicode__ and if it does not exist, attempt unicode translation of obj.__str__. So it really seems like __str__ should be sufficient.

Maybe with the traceback we can figure out more and potentially add a test that will catch this on any hardware/locale."}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-05-18 15:19:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mark, unfortunately I only saw this problem on my Mac OS 10.6. I recently upgraded to Lion (10.7) and my Python version is 2.7 now. So I can't get the traceback. But unicode(exception) just don't call __str__ for whatever reason in that python version..

In the following link Paul Du Bois in comment reported a similar problem with the Exception class for Python 2.6.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1307014/python-str-versus-unicode"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-18 15:46:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Hmm, a shame. I guess we could alter the test_deserialize_remote_exception_user_defined_exception test method to directly assert the existence of both __str__ and __unicode__ on the exception object. But I have doubts about how important the test really is.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-23 17:22:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-23 20:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Fixes lp:1002135. Minor re-factor to rest client

Bug 920817 was fixed in Essex. This patch re-factors the rest client correctly
set the management url depending on the public URL returned by keystone and
the service client subclass requesting the URL.

Change-Id: If5e6b5d5287daa2137c20515d18babb105ab5ee8

commit_message:
Permit deleted instance types to be queried for active instances.

Fixes bug 994935.

This removes the deleted=0 restriction for joining instance_types
to instances. Active instances may be using old/deleted instance_types,
so we still need to be able to look up that information for show/detail
requests.

Change-Id: Ica72801f19c7e5b04966e53ed3ea4c330df44ed1

commit_message:
Make validate_compacted_migration into general diff tool.

This patch removes some assumptions from the tool and turns it in to a
generalized schema diffing tool where any two versions of the DB schema,
represented by branch-version pairs, can be diffed.

To reflect the more genernal nature, the name was changed to
schema_diff.py.

Change-Id: I4dc233fa2d4b084779922893f76baa753fe2c126

My only real nag is 

QUOTA = quota.QUOTA

Shouldn't it be

QUOTA = quota.Quota? or Quota()
(didn't spend much time looking at the innards honestly)"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-05-16 17:47:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-16 19:43:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Kevin,

I'm seeing the following issue when deleting (cleanup up instances) w/ this branch:

BadRequest: Change would make usage less than 0 for the following resources: ['cores', 'instances', 'ram']"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-16 21:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (5 inline comments)

See in-line for responses.  A look at the torpedo makes me wonder how the smokestack tests are set up; I had a few unit tests I had to adapt that directly modified the database (without, of course, updating the corresponding usage).  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-16 21:45:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sandy: "QUOTAS = quota.QUOTAS" is an idiom I more or less copied from the "FLAGS = flags.FLAGS".  QUOTAS is an instance of class QuotaEngine, which contains the list of quota resources.  Because the quota resources are needed in multiple services (-api, -compute, etc.), it's easiest to declare them in one place, quota.py, which is going to be pulled in by everything that needs to do a quota operation.

Dan: What's supposed to happen is that you create an instance, and once it's finished being created (nominally, as soon as there's a database entry), the usage gets updated.  When you then delete the instance, the usage gets decremented.  If you create a database entry directly, especially after a usage has already been created, your "in_use" value may be too low, and then deleting the instance using the standard delete interface will raise that "less than zero" error.  This is my best guess as to why you might be seeing that error; I did have to touch a couple of unit tests to stub out the quota check because they used that sort of idiom.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-17 17:56:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hey, Sandy / Dan—have I addressed ya'll's concerns?  Any suggestions?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-17 19:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Kevin:

So. I think you might have misunderstood my last comment. I'm seeing SmokeStack failures with this branch when using Torpedo. The failure I see is:

BadRequest: Change would make usage less than 0 for the following resources: ['cores', 'instances', 'ram']

This occurs when trying to delete a server that was both created and deleted via the API. Torpedo always has and always will use the API exclusively. There is no manual DB entry into the servers table, etc.

If you need to reproduce I'm happy to spin up a group we can both 'jump into' and debug the issue."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-18 14:09:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Dan: Well, I didn't misunderstand you, I just didn't understand how smokestack did its tests :)  Now that I know, I'll take a look through the code and see if I can pinpoint the problem; instances were the most complex to implement."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:47:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:48:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Dan: Please let me know if this helps your issue.  If it doesn't, could you show me the sequence of operations that test tries to do?"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-19 00:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

I have two patch comment'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 14:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:04:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:05:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

This version does something a little different with negative usage counts...'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(4 inline comments)

Very nice overall.  The new quota system looks to handle race conditions better now and has a pluggable driver design consistent with other Nova layers.

I made some minor in-line comments.  You might also want to document how the quota system works somewhere also.  Maybe a module level docstring on nova/quota.py?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:40:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (4 inline comments)

Having some form of documentation would probably be indicated.  I won't add it to this patch unless I need to (really trying to get this in before skew kills it), but I'll think about the best way of doing that.

(For reference, a great many of our other systems could likewise benefit from similar developer docs :)"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-22 14:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I believe all comments and issues have been addressed; please let me know if I missed or forgot something.  All this needs is another +2/approval…'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-05-23 14:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Finish quota refactor.

Finishes quota refactoring by making use of the new quota infrastructure.
Partially implements blueprint quota-refactor (the final piece is to
remove the old quota architecture).

This change is fairly substantial.  To make it easier to review, it has been
broken up into 3 parts.  This is the second part.

Change-Id: I1c8b43198f0d44e9e13a45575361aa043fd0639e

commit_message:
Replace git url with github zipball.

distribute does not grok git urls, but auto-generated zipfiles are a
short-term workaround until we've got pypi uploads sorted.

Fixes bug 1003328

Change-Id: Iaded7245cea7a30c2f421c7b48ece9823aaf152f

subject: Use utils.parse_strtime rather than datetime.strptime
messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-21 12:58:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The changes look correct, but what's the value in using utils.parse_strtime() in these cases?  It looks like the only value it provides is in the case where you don't provide a time format string."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-21 13:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Russell,
Well it's just to make the code DRY. parse_strtime still does need a time format to parse it."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-21 13:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I mean parse the string to datetime'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-21 13:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I just mean that it has a default format string:

    def parse_strtime(timestr, fmt=PERFECT_TIME_FORMAT):
        """Turn a formatted time back into a datetime."""
        return datetime.datetime.strptime(timestr, fmt)

It doesn't really add any value when you pass both a timstr and fmt ... but I guess if we're going to use the wrapper in some places, it's best to be consistent and use it everywhere.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-23 12:42:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Looks fine. Couple minor nits to cleanup the unused 'datetime' imports in 3 of the files."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-23 14:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-23 14:26:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

subject: Don't allow active instance types to be deleted.
messages:
[{'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-22 17:53:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While this seems reasonable on the surface, is it really a valid assumption that because you no longer want to create *new* instances of an expired type, that you also want to destroy all existing instances of that type?

Perhaps it would be better not to delete instance types at all, but to flag them as inactive/unavailable for the creation of new instances?'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:00:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure what you're referring to about destroying all instances of a specific type? This only prevents the instance _type_ from being marked as deleted -- not active instances themselves.

When an instance type is destroyed, it is essentially just marked as disabled. Nothing is actually deleted from the table. As suggested in the bug report, one could just flip the deleted bit back to 1 to bring them back."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

*flip the deleted bit back to 0'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:08:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

With this patch, to mark an instance type as deleted you will need to destroy all instances of that type. (right?)

In a large-scale production environment, this would make it effectively impossible to delete an instance type out of the box. You won't be able to stop new instances from being launched of that type, and you'd fight to destroy those instances against the incoming horde of launch requests. Unless you blocked the external API entirely...

That is also assuming you want the behavior of having to destroy *existing* instances just because you don't want *new* instances to have a particular type."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah, yeah, I see what you are saying. I will go back and check the specs to see what is expected and start a conversation on the ML if need be.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:11:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Formalizing the -1"}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Just an optimization question.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:44:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's what I had originally, but it was causing the unit tests to fail in sqlite. For whatever reason, even when manually the deleted attribute in the test instance, it wasn't matching correctly in the filters."}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2012-05-22 19:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, I understand, but the whole "For whatever reason" thing sounds worrisome. If your tests are not accurately testing things...'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-22 19:28:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I get what you're saying and agree. It's an issue with the filters query and sqlite, but that fix will be in a different branch (since this one will likely be abandoned anyway)."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-23 16:15:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

Fixes bug 994935.

Change-Id: I23999bc29aa7eeb75ee277c6de8ec019bb1295ef
"}]

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:11:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey Rick,

Nice job on this. Perhaps a simple README on how to run and make use of the tool would be helpful?

Also, I'm 50/50 on whether this sort of tool would be better written in Bash vs. Python. Given the number of subprocess commands it might be less code/easier to understand if written in Shell."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:27:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

Great idea for a tool, now people just have to remember it exists with each release cycle or rope it into some test automation somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:37:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Perhaps a simple README on how to run and make use of the tool would be helpful?

Rather than a separate README, would expanding the header docstring be good enough? I like, especially for programmer-focused tools, keeping the code and documentation as close together as possible

> Also, I'm 50/50 on whether this sort of tool would be better written in Bash vs. Python. Given the number of subprocess commands it might be less code/easier to understand if written in Shell.

Yeah I considered that at first. Leaned against that because, in my experience, scripts that that do anything beyond trivial, linear execution of commands, tend to get rewritten in a more feature-rich scripting language at some point. If nothing else, just to get access to a sane option parsing library.

That said, if I get a moment, I might spike out a bash version, and if it is dramatically cleaner, I'll go w/ that."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-21 15:39:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Nits

Plus: regarding the bash argument, I've never looked at code before and said to myself "Man, I can't understand this Python/Ruby/C/LISP/Sanskrit, I wish it'd been written in bash." I much prefer the python that's been done here. Also, agree with the docstring as documentation rather than a README. I'm much more likely to find it when I'm invariably looking at the code before I run something as nefarious-sounding as this script ;-)'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-22 21:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-23 14:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks nice, thanks :)'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-05-23 16:04:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-23 16:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Add migration compaction validation tool.

This tool can be used to diff the schemas pre and post migration to
validate that nothing fundamental has changed during the compaction
process.

Change-Id: I178c849aa93467898a7c9bf1d2128d28af1b1ad4

commit_message:
make nova bash-complete faster and more accurate

- cache output of "nova bash-complete"
- distinguish between flags and commands (based on already typed text)

Change-Id: I85bd1c2198eef222540cf12063a3b233b0d6db12

[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-14 14:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-15 21:45:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-16 06:53:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

What do you think about making the rpcapi accept the instance object, so we're prepared for passing it via RPC vs passing only the uuid and forcing the worker to do a DB lookup?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 12:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 12:32:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Chris - that's a good idea.  I know the compute manager was already doing something like that, so I should have followed that.  I'll get this updated to work that way."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 15:24:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 15:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

rev 5 includes suggested improvements from Chris'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 16:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-16 21:08:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-16 22:14:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(8 inline comments)

There's a minor behavior difference, I think.  Tell me if I'm missing it.

The old code for casting/calling to compute verifies that instance['host'] is set... (unless a host argument was passed in).  It'll raise that there's no compute host for the instance.

The new code will just blindly assume compute['host'] is set, as far as I can tell.  As long as our state checking is okay, I think this behavior is fine... because I don't think we ever unset 'host' once it's set.  However, if there's some sort of action that makes it past state checking.. and the instance is not scheduled yet...  we'll end up casting a message to just 'compute'.. and I think that's undesirable.  We should probably just raise.

Also, I think I spotted 1 real bug in rpcapi with use of 'host' vs 'host_param'.

The other nit I have is that your calls to rpcapi all use keyword args when the definitions are really positional required args. :)  I guess it's nice to not have to remember the argument order, but when I see the calling side, I tend to think there's a lot of optional arguments.  Anyway, that's just a nit and I'm not really asking it for it to be fixed.  I'm concerned about the other 2 issues above.

As I mentioned on IRC, I do like the centralizing of the rpc message generation!  Makes it easier if we ever change formats, for one."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-17 15:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-14 13:38:58.000000000', 'message': "Add version to scheduler rpc API.

Part of blueprint versioned-rpc-apis.

One side effect of this change was that nova.scheduler.api was removed
in favor of nova.scheduler.rpcapi.  In this case, the api was just a
direct wrapper around rpc usage.  For other APIs, I've been following
the pattern that the rpcapi module provides the rpc client wrapper, and
if any other client-side logic is needed, that's where an api module is
used.

Change-Id: Ibd0292936f9afc77aeb5d040660bfa857861eed1

commit_message:
Add version to scheduler rpc API.

Part of blueprint versioned-rpc-apis.

One side effect of this change was that nova.scheduler.api was removed
in favor of nova.scheduler.rpcapi.  In this case, the api was just a
direct wrapper around rpc usage.  For other APIs, I've been following
the pattern that the rpcapi module provides the rpc client wrapper, and
if any other client-side logic is needed, that's where an api module is
used.

Change-Id: Ibd0292936f9afc77aeb5d040660bfa857861eed1

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-09 20:40:55.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix nova-manage backend_add with sr_uuid"

Fixes bug 988596

Change 77495cfe breaks storage manager, as it makes a
wrong assumption about nova-manage. The sr-uuid must be
generated and provided by the xenapi storage manager.

When the volume service is started, SM volume driver will
create a new SR for everything that does not have an
existing sr_uuid and will populate the db with the result.
It will only introduce the SRs that do have one. The introduce
will work only if the uuid provided is something SM understands.

This reverts commit 77495cfed17f12f225e11fbc10e0f8db516dadf2.

Change-Id: Ifa35484f1fe274f454bba2ac8727d2d56c18fd75

wrong assumption about nova-manage. The sr-uuid must be
generated and provided by the xenapi storage manager.

When the volume service is started, SM volume driver will
create a new SR for everything that does not have an
existing sr_uuid and will populate the db with the result.
It will only introduce the SRs that do have one. The introduce
will work only if the uuid provided is something SM understands.

This partially reverts commit 77495cfed17f12f225e11fbc10e0f8db516dadf2.
Changes in db are left intact.

Change-Id: Ifa35484f1fe274f454bba2ac8727d2d56c18fd75
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Fix nova-manage backend_add with sr_uuid"

Fixes bug 988596

Change 77495cfe breaks storage manager, as it makes a
wrong assumption about nova-manage. The sr-uuid must be
generated and provided by the xenapi storage manager.

When the volume service is started, SM volume driver will
create a new SR for everything that does not have an
existing sr_uuid and will populate the db with the result.
It will only introduce the SRs that do have one. The introduce
will work only if the uuid provided is something SM understands.

This partially reverts commit 77495cfed17f12f225e11fbc10e0f8db516dadf2.
Changes in db are left intact.

Change-Id: Ifa35484f1fe274f454bba2ac8727d2d56c18fd75

subject: Import openstack.common.cfg directly
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The fallback needs to be updated since this will throw ImportError when it doesn't exist in the namespace."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I had to make this change to be able to run update.py on my machine. Not sure how it works for anyone else.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It only causes a problem when openstack.common is not installed. If it is installed, then there is no issue. The fallback workaround was just for convince so you don't have to install openstack.common just to copy the code into the projects."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Any details on why it wasn't working before, like a trackback or error or something? Just want to know what the bug was this fixes."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ah, I see and the openstack namespace isn't already defined since you probably don't have openstack.nose_plugin installed either. So this makes sense. The imp works it just is throwing an ImportError as well not an AttributeError which is what gets thrown if the namespace is defined. Try changing line 68 to:

   except AttributeError, ImportError:

And let me know if that falls back correctly."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It is needed for when the nose plugin (which shares the openstack namespace) is installed but openstack.common is not installed (just a bare checkout). Since the openstack namespace is declared in the site-packages or where-ever, python doesn't use the openstack namespace found in ./.

I'm not sure why the assignment doesn't work. It would be interesting to see what the error was. In the bug johannes put a better fallback patch, but never merge prop'd it."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think this only happens when you are in an activated virtualenv that removes the '' entry from sys.path. Please confirm this is the case. In which case the question then becomes why did the fallback of catching the AttributeError not work?"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can you try it in a blank venv then, it sounds like you have the openstack namespace defined by another package (perhaps the nose_plugin is installed). This is the noted bug, since when you define a namespace folders in ./ are not automatically merged with that namespace until installation, hence falling back to the imp import to import the module directly.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure how that import ever worked. If I create a directory structure of /a/b/c with __init__.py's in /a and /a/b then run the following python snippet:

from a import b
b.c

This raises:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'c'

I guess everybody that uses this script has the openstack common code installed locally? This isn't making much sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

'cfg = common.cfg' raises an AttributeError, but I don't expect it to raise anything at all... I'm also running this from the root openstack-common project dir, so the openstack namespace is defined locally."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I wasn't in a venv when I ran update.py or when I did the test with a/b/c. The a/b/c test also doesn't work with imp.find_module..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Is there any interest in landing this patch?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah, agree with Jason - more details please

It's not clear to me what this fixes or why

Also, what about Joannes patch in bug #951197 ?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ok, I don't know understand a) we needed the "Workaround for LP951197" thing in the first place nor b) why "cfg = common.cfg" doesn't work for bcwaldon

Jason - any change you can clear the fog for us on both of those?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If the nose plugin causes problems with production code imports, shouldn't it be moved to a separate namespace?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Having it only fail sometimes seems even more confusing. :-)

Obviously you've already worked around it, but this looks like an area to consider cleaning up in the future."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

'}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-05-18 17:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The syntax and ideology are fine. One consideration: people may consider it a security risk to have the admin pass stored in their shell's history. Should we perhaps add some language warning people about that, and provide an alternative method of getting the pass into the variable, such as:

"If you do not with to have the swift admin password stored in your shell's history, you may perform the following:
export SWIFT_PROXY_CONF="/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf
export ADMINPASS=$( grep super_admin_key ${SWIFT_PROXY_CONF} | awk '{ print $NF }' )
"

Or something similar?'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-20 01:01:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-05-20 12:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

bug 999005 -set ADMINPASS to fix swift example

exports the ADMINPASS set earlier in the document to allow example
commands to work in this section
Added note about avoiding bash history storage of admin password
fixes bug 999005

subject: Add ACL check using <tenant_id>:<user> format.
messages: [{'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-05-23 04:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nThis commit should have generated a Patch Set 2 for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7656/. Cancelling this one, need to figure out the issue.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-23 04:40:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add ACL check using <tenant_id>:<user> format.

Fixes bug 999998.

Swift auth middleware uses a new format for expressing
a container ACL for a user: <tenant_name>:<user>. This
fix add supports for checking ACL using the old format
of <tenant_id>:<user>.

Change-Id: I909b9f2301d5be47b5f1f1cd9617f10df86cfb95
'}]
commit_message:
Add ACL check using <tenant_id>:<user> format.

Fixes bug 999998.

Swift auth middleware uses a new format for expressing
a container ACL for a user: <tenant_name>:<user>. This
fix add supports for checking ACL using the old format
of <tenant_id>:<user>.

Change-Id: I909b9f2301d5be47b5f1f1cd9617f10df86cfb95

commit_message:
Adds initial workflow support to Horizon.

Implements blueprint workflows.

Adds a reusable workflow component to Horizon, and puts it
to use for the Launch Instance user interface. Contains
tests with roughly 90% coverage and full documentation.

Change-Id: I7325ef9db2ba2496d3fc1e2767cfeda50c71cbca

commit_message:
Use --debug to enable printing HTTP message(s) between client and
server, besides logging verbosely.

fix Bug #993859

change --verbose into --debug, which is a practice by other clients
(nova and glance).
note: httplib prints message by print.
Patch 2: fix pep8, modify according to some comments
Change-Id: Ibc959cca7d89c18b6d5c902f2e98bb856102c51c

openstack_dashboard instead of openstack-dashboard
* updates the location of manage.py

[{'created': '2012-05-15 17:34:07.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor HTTPClient to use two request methods

Rather than depend on magic, I would prefer that we explicitly call
two different request methods: json_request and raw_request. The
former will encode/decode request bodies to and from JSON, while
the latter will not.

Change-Id: I6a429a5975993f71df85df55f11c5d51c050c289
'}, {'created': '2012-05-22 15:45:02.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor HTTPClient to use two request methods

Rather than depend on magic, I would prefer that we explicitly call
two different request methods: json_request and raw_request. The

Change-Id: I6a429a5975993f71df85df55f11c5d51c050c289

commit_message:
Refactor HTTPClient to use two request methods

Rather than depend on magic, I would prefer that we explicitly call
two different request methods: json_request and raw_request. The
former will encode/decode request bodies to and from JSON, while
the latter will not.

Change-Id: I6a429a5975993f71df85df55f11c5d51c050c289

commit_message:
Add connection timeout to glance client.

Adds a timeout option to glance client and bin/glance.
Includes fast running test case to verify the timeout works correctly.

Fixes LP Bug #1002907.

Change-Id: I4a0c4a8ef1862346ec2cd068d9d9e0577cba9b68

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-17 18:50:41.000000000', 'message': 'Create new swift data store filesystem every time

The Swift data store was not cleaned out between stack.sh runs; although
the contents were not visible they were still taking up space.  Create a
new XFS filesystem on every stack.sh run.

Fixes bug 1000827

Change-Id: Ieab6b5f65b7964906f244975cbcdf2cf50344ca5
'}]
commit_message:
Create new swift data store filesystem every time

The Swift data store was not cleaned out between stack.sh runs; although
the contents were not visible they were still taking up space.  Create a
new XFS filesystem on every stack.sh run.

Fixes bug 1000827

Change-Id: Ieab6b5f65b7964906f244975cbcdf2cf50344ca5

     Fixes bug 979417.

commit_message:
Instance table minor fixes.

  1. Don't display terminate action for paused instance.
     Fixes bug 979417.
  2. Don't poll on paused status in syspanel instances table.
     Fixes bug 979443.

Change-Id: I7d5b515eb8572c681898e46de355e777539f9944

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/329/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-22 17:55:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks for working on improving the docs Gary!

In general, my main goal is to have things documented in a small set of key places, so our docs our easy to find, and update.  

It looks like the text in index.rst is taken from: http://wiki.openstack.org/Quantum .  Copying it here means things have to be updated in two locations, and are likely to get out of date.  I'd rather link to this content, than copy it.  

Also, the content of quantum-server.rst probably belongs in the Quantum Admin Guide: http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-network/admin/content/index.html, as this is documentation for any USER of Quantum (this doc is part of the openstack/openstack-manuals repo:  https://github.com/openstack/openstack-manuals/blob/master/doc/src/docbkx/openstack-network-connectivity-admin/quantum-admin-guide.xml ).

My understanding is that the rst docs are supposed to be developer documentation moving forward (this is a bit confusing when you look at other services, as nova originally used their rst docs as user documentation, but I believe they are ripping all of that out.  

I will add Anne Gentle from the openstack docs team to this bug to add comments.  

I dont' want to discourage you from doing docs (we badly need more people contributing there), but I want to make sure we do it in a way that's simple for users, consistent with other openstack doc efforts, and maintainable moving forward.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-22 17:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-22 17:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-22 16:05:12.000000000', 'message': 'Make devstack nodes jenkins slaves.

Add them as nodes with the tag "devstack-IMAGE" where IMAGE is, eg,
oneiric, with a single executor.  Change the reap job to delete
these jenkins nodes.  Change the delete script to simply mark them
for deletion.  It should then be called by a new job that is a
post-build step for the devstack gate job.  Another new job should
be called as the first build step in the devstack gate, and it should
invoke devstack-vm-inprogress.py to disable the node that the job
just started running on.  In this manner, we end up with single-use
jenkins slaves.

Change the gate script to expect to be run the host itself, so it
no longer needs to ssh and scp/rsync files around.

Add a new script, devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh, which assists running
the gate job on a separate devstack host, as is currently done,
to test it out without requiring the full Jenkins infrastructure.

Change-Id: I28902918406670163d32ae7c2a644055233dc1fa
'}]
commit_message:
Make devstack nodes jenkins slaves.

Add them as nodes with the tag "devstack-IMAGE" where IMAGE is, eg,
oneiric, with a single executor.  Change the reap job to delete
these jenkins nodes.  Change the delete script to simply mark them
for deletion.  It should then be called by a new job that is a
post-build step for the devstack gate job.  Another new job should
be called as the first build step in the devstack gate, and it should
invoke devstack-vm-inprogress.py to disable the node that the job
just started running on.  In this manner, we end up with single-use
jenkins slaves.

Change the gate script to expect to be run the host itself, so it
no longer needs to ssh and scp/rsync files around.

Add a new script, devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh, which assists running
the gate job on a separate devstack host, as is currently done,
to test it out without requiring the full Jenkins infrastructure.

Change-Id: I28902918406670163d32ae7c2a644055233dc1fa

subject: Add headroom reporting to os-quota-sets extension
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

As a note, I'm currently working on rewriting quotas to get around the race condition bug 938317.  A side-effect of my changes would be to have a table of usages that will show how many of each resource is currently in use.  We may want to coordinate our efforts; to see what I've got so far, see:

    https://github.com/klmitch/nova/tree/quota-atomicity"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:16:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-28 19:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hey, let's coordinate our efforts…"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:45:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Kevin,

Thanks for the heads-up on your related development work.

Absolutely, lets co-ordinate our efforts on this.

So, there are a couple of different approaches we could take:

1. Allow this patch onto master and then later retrofit it to leverage the re-factored quotas extension to determine current usage.

2. Hold up this patch, while integrating it with your work-in-progress quotas mechanism.

I would favor #1, just to avoid this and the related novaclient patch going stale. I would of course be happy to take responsibility for that retrofitting work.

Do you OTOH think approach #2 is absolutely necessary? i.e. is there some aspect of the patch that would impede later integration with your re-factoring efforts?

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-28 22:11:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Well, I'm doing some deep surgery on quotas.  One of the side effects is that I'm replacing get_project_quotas() with a method that can return usage data as well (both in_use and reserved, the sum of which will be used in quota checks for how much is currently used).  That automatically gets you your data, but changes some of your code.

(I actually thought you touched more code than you actually do, so we may be able to resolve our approaches more easily than I initially thought.  Still, it's worth touching base...)

Have you looked at http://etherpad.openstack.org/quota-atomicity yet?  Also, https://github.com/klmitch/nova/compare/master...quota-atomicity may be useful for you to see what I'm doing.  (I'm about to make another push to that branch, with a bunch more code added…)"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-29 12:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Kevin,

I've reviewed your etherpad and added an observation on the possibility of negative headroom arising from administrative quota threshold reduction (a pre-existing problem).

I like the idea of reservations being used to capture the intent to allocate some resource, in order to avoid the threshold being breached due the pace of requests for resources out-stripping their actual allocation.

However, I don't see any clash between our objectives here, nor the need to hold a mutex on development in the quotas area. 

As I said, I would be happy to integrate headroom reporting with the new reservation-aware mechanism. I may have missed something, but it would seem that this would involve just changing the basis of the headroom calculation, i.e. in simplistic terms replacing:

  headroom = threshold - used

with:

  headroom = threshold - (used + reserved)

Do you see an additional impact?

If not, I would like this patch to be considered on its merits, but your -1 is likely to inhibite other reviews (good, bad, or indifferent) of the patch itself.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-29 13:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-29 13:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Remove some stray debugging from test.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:24:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yeah, I was only keeping the -1 on there so it didn't get approved before we finished talking.  I approve of your suggestion, so no more -1 from me…"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-03 14:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-18 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-18 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Restored

Automated expiry due to a lack of nova-core reviewer attention to this patch.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-04-27 17:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Would this be considered a major change rather than a minor one? From my understanding of minor versions they indicate backwards-compatibility but this patch changes the type of the resource from an integer to an object containing more detailed information. Can existing clients use this extension? I would think that a backward compatible change would be just adding the /headroom resource?'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-30 11:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks for the review Brian,

By a backward-compatible change, were you suggesting that the pre-existing query, e.g.:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id

would just return the old-style response:

  {"quota_set": {
    "floating_ips": 10,
    "instances": 10,
    ...
  }}

instead of:

  {"quota_set": {
    "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10},
    "instances": {"threshold": 10},
  }}

?

Then the new headroom query would return either:

(a) *both* the threshold and the headroom (as in the current patch set):

   {"quota_set": {
       "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 5},
       "instances": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 4},
       ...
    }}

OR:

(b) just the headroom in the same format as the existing threshold query:

  {"quota_set": {
       "floating_ips": 5,
       "instances": 4,
       ...
  }}

Seems to me that (a) would be most useful as many clients would want to know *both* the threshold & headroom, whereas (b) would be least inconsistent with the existing threshold query.

Or would another approach be to bump the API extension's version to 2.0 and somehow allow the v2.0 extension co-exist with v1.1 so that pre-existing external clients (other than python-novaclient, if there are any such clients) would continue to work as before.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:20:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Spot on. I don't even know if there *are* clients out there right now but I'm always worried about breaking compatibility.

In the ideal world I'd say we would use your solution (b) to make the v1.x extension return just the threshold for the basic query and just the headroom for the new headroom query added in v1.2.

Then, the v2.0 extension would be more efficient because we've learned what the customer wants.

v1.x and v2.x could live simultaneously in the code-base IMO as long as we had a bug/issue to deprecate/delete the v1.x version at release of F or G!"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:05:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm hoping to finish my quotas patch this week.  Perhaps we should talk and see if we can merge your functionality into my patch, in an appropriately backwards-compatible way…"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-22 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-22 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-28 16:07:56.000000000', 'message': 'Add headroom reporting to os-quota-sets extension

Fixes bug 967198

The os-quota-sets API extension now reports both the quota
threshold and the headroom to reflect current usage, and to
give early indication of impending resource starvation.

To facilitate this change, the quota_set representation has
been modified to nest the threshold value in a subelement,
alongside the headroom in a sibling subelement.

The (threshold-only) show action now plays out as:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/json

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/json
  {"quota_set": {
     "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10},
     "instances": {"threshold": 10},
     "cores": {"threshold": 20},
     ...,
     "id": tenant_id}
  }

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/xml

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/xml
  <quota_set id="tenant_id">
    <floating_ips>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
    </floating_ips>
    <instances>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
    </instances>
    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

whereas the headroom verb includes the remaining headroom for
each quota representing a limit on overall resource usage that
may grow or shrink over time:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id/headroom
  Accept: application/json

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/json
  {"quota_set": {
     "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 5},
     "instances": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 4},
     "cores": {"threshold": 20, "headroom": 14},
     ...,
     "id": tenant_id}
  }

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/xml

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/xml
  <quota_set id="tenant_id">
    <floating_ips>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
      <headroom>5</headroom>
    </floating_ips>
    <instances>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
      <headroom>4</headroom>
    </instances>
    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
      <headroom>14</headroom>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

As the quota_set representation has been changed, the version of the
API extension namepsace is bumped to:

  http://docs.openstack.org/compute/ext/quotas-sets/api/v1.2

Change-Id: I8bd9cdcd2d29c4b33d9b406aa6ea02e366fd3e7c
'}, {'created': '2012-03-28 16:45:22.000000000', 'message': 'Add headroom reporting to os-quota-sets extension

    </floating_ips>
    <instances>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
    </instances>
    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

whereas the headroom verb includes the remaining headroom for
each quota representing a limit on overall resource usage that
may grow or shrink over time:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id/headroom
  Accept: application/json

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/json
  {"quota_set": {
     "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 5},
     "instances": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 4},
     "cores": {"threshold": 20, "headroom": 14},
     ...,
     "id": tenant_id}
  }

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/xml

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/xml
  <quota_set id="tenant_id">
    <floating_ips>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
      <headroom>5</headroom>

    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
      <headroom>14</headroom>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

As the quota_set representation has been changed, the version of the
API extension namepsace is bumped to:

  http://docs.openstack.org/compute/ext/quotas-sets/api/v1.2

commit_message:
Add headroom reporting to os-quota-sets extension

Fixes bug 967198

The os-quota-sets API extension now reports both the quota
threshold and the headroom to reflect current usage, and to
give early indication of impending resource starvation.

To facilitate this change, the quota_set representation has
been modified to nest the threshold value in a subelement,
alongside the headroom in a sibling subelement.

The (threshold-only) show action now plays out as:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/json

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/json
  {"quota_set": {
     "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10},
     "instances": {"threshold": 10},
     "cores": {"threshold": 20},
     ...,
     "id": tenant_id}
  }

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/xml

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/xml
  <quota_set id="tenant_id">
    <floating_ips>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
    </floating_ips>
    <instances>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
    </instances>
    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

whereas the headroom verb includes the remaining headroom for
each quota representing a limit on overall resource usage that
may grow or shrink over time:

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id/headroom
  Accept: application/json

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/json
  {"quota_set": {
     "floating_ips": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 5},
     "instances": {"threshold": 10, "headroom": 4},
     "cores": {"threshold": 20, "headroom": 14},
     ...,
     "id": tenant_id}
  }

  GET /v2/tenant_id/os-quota-sets/tenant_id
  Accept: application/xml

  HTTP/1.1 200 OK
  Content-Type: application/xml
  <quota_set id="tenant_id">
    <floating_ips>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
      <headroom>5</headroom>
    </floating_ips>
    <instances>
      <threshold>10</threshold>
      <headroom>4</headroom>
    </instances>
    <cores>
      <threshold>20</threshold>
      <headroom>14</headroom>
    </cores>
    ...
  </quota_set>

As the quota_set representation has been changed, the version of the
API extension namepsace is bumped to:

  http://docs.openstack.org/compute/ext/quotas-sets/api/v1.2

Change-Id: I8bd9cdcd2d29c4b33d9b406aa6ea02e366fd3e7c

commit_message:
Add ACL check using <tenant_id>:<user> format.

Fixes bug 999998.

Swift auth middleware uses a new format for expressing a container ACL for a user: <tenant_name>:<user>. This fix add supports for checking ACL using the old format
of <tenant_id>:<user>.

Change-Id: I3d66250cd53b69f06aa90298552e217dd9ac5c6c

commit_message:
bug 948242 make doc use 'Administration' consistently

Changes the title and reference to titles of documents previously called
 "Admin Guide/Manual" to be "Administration Guide/Manual", as suggested in
bug 948242

Patched to get the Quantum Administrator Manual title to wrap correctly in PDF output.

Removes the object storage monitoring chapter - while it applies mostly to essex, some of it
does not apply and should probably revised for a second patch. I am guessing this based on the
comments in the blog entry itself at http://swiftstack.com/blog/2012/04/11/swift-monitoring-with-statsd/.

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7480/

Change-Id: I360d74c5ad16650c7b838541bb976680c0297b26

subject: Move proxy server logging to middleware.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 512, 'name': 'Mike Barton', 'username': '5UOzf3BLEHnnEzgp', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 597, 'name': 'Pete Zaitcev', 'email': 'zaitcev@kotori.zaitcev.us', 'username': 'zaitcev'}, {'_account_id': 995, 'name': 'David Goetz', 'email': 'david.goetz@rackspace.com', 'username': 'david-goetz'}, {'_account_id': 1216, 'name': 'gholt', 'email': 'z-launchpad@brim.net', 'username': 'gholt'}, {'_account_id': 1603, 'name': 'Florian Hines', 'email': 'syn@ronin.io', 'username': 'pandemicsyn'}, {'_account_id': 2828, 'name': 'Michael Barton', 'email': 'mike@weirdlooking.com', 'username': 'redbo'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-14 14:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

swift/common/middleware/proxy_logging.py:152:9: E301 expected 1 blank line, found 0

This is called proxy_logging in some places, access-logging in others. With where it is suggested in the pipeline, it seems like access-logging would be the proper name.

However, with this change some requests will be double-logged due to folks writing middleware that emulates the old proxy logging. I think the double-logged thing should be fine; I'm not aware of any places were it would be a big issue, but maybe something to consider.

I am worried we'd be losing the logging for "subrequests" -- requests that middleware makes to get its job done. For instance, swauth and staticweb (and the future sos) subrequests would go silent.

Maybe it really should be called proxy-logging everywhere and go just outside the proxy in the pipeline?

If this were a brand new project, I'd rather each middleware piece log it's own subrequests and not log the overall request (which would get caught by your new middleware); but unfortunately this isn't greenfield. :/'}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2012-03-14 21:30:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There's some logic behind when it's called which name, but I can change that to be globally uniform.

Obviously it'll make billing processing more complex if the logging middleware is above something like swift3 or staticweb instead of below.

But it's also pretty sucky that what gets logged right now may not reflect the user's actual request and response, and stuff that gets rejected in middleware won't be access logged at all.  I don't know what the right thing is.  I'll move it down next to the app in the examples so it mimics the old behavior until I figure out how the world is supposed to work."}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2012-03-14 22:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-15 04:07:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

swift/common/middleware/proxy_logging.py:152:9: E301 expected 1 blank line, found 0

It'd probably be a good time to stanardize the "or '-'" stuff, probably just put it at the top "quote(str(x)) if x else '-'" or something.

proxy_logging.py lines 81:82 aren't tested (client disconnect)'}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2012-03-15 20:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 01:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

There's a leftover "print log_parts" in the new test, but we can get rid of that later.'}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2012-03-16 01:16:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 01:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-03-20 02:26:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-03-20 19:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2012-03-21 21:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

investigating possible bug- please no merging'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-22 02:09:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Thanks to dfg's find, I recommend the following patch (as well as a patch to StaticWeb ( https://review.openstack.org/#change,5660 ):

https://gist.github.com/2155149"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-22 02:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Note that even with my patch, requests that never even yield the first "chunk" (immediate disconnects) will not get logged. commit_message:
Add "dist:precise" to qpidd.

It is also marked NOPRIME, but some setups (devstack-gate) would
like to cache, but not install, all .debs to avoid false negative
tests due to network problems.  This way it can be cached only on
appropriate platforms.

Change-Id: Ia4216e9e8e6e7f55bf5fe9bc683fee97976a9b04

I'm not convinced that an exception is necessary in this case. IMO, we should just silently strip out invalid characters and allow the type to be created."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm not sure this should transparently substitute characters, returning an error is better. Tools that attempt to create a flavor with a given name will receive a successful return value, but the name created will not be as requested, thus it is not deterministic."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:56:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey Josh -

How about a:
raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg)

instead of just auto-fixing the name?  It seems like it would be consistent with the other argument validation going on.

subject: Work around table creation race.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-16 16:45:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-16 19:05:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Brian, response to comment inline.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-17 19:31:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My preference would be to stop glance-registry from creating its tables altogether.

At the conference I *think* I managed to convince Jay this was a good idea...

Waldon/Eogan: what do you think? Wouldn't it just be better to eliminate this situation entirely and rely on 'glance-manage db_sync' instead to create DB tables?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-17 21:42:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan: yes, I've lost touch with all this db stuff recently and don't really know what its current behavior even is. I would definitely prefer to do less automatically."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 13:47:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@dprince/bcwaldon

At this stage I really just want the glance tests to stop randomly failing in my dev env.

If supressing DB auto-create is what it takes to get this done, then so be it.

I'll submit another patch that adds a new config option to control whether the Db is auto-created or not."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-18 16:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dan is correct; I agreed at the summit to get rid of the auto-creation DB stuff --- BUT, I said I would prefer that the migration code be standardized, fixed, and moved to openstack-common and imported into Glance. Frankly, we spend WAY too much time reworking the migration crap and we really need to have a centralized, controlled, standard way of dealing with them... thus my push to openstack-common-ize it.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Superceded by https://review.openstack.org/7582'}]

commit_message:
Work around table creation race.

Fixes bug 1000304

Allow table creation to fail if caused by it having just been
created by the other glance service.

Change-Id: I136b0e881cc051a98088155c525a2c0c579ae2ed

subject: Support DB auto-create suppression.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-18 15:55:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The functionality is definitely needed, though I don't think the interface needs to be split between 'create' and 'sync'.
It seems like the db_sync could remain and auto create as needed."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 16:35:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 16:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 16:44:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Superfluous db_create command rolled into db_sync for consistency with nova & keystone.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-18 16:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

So if one configures db_auto_create=False,
will db_sync create the db?

Seems db_sync should should ensure that
db_auto_create=True?'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 17:28:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks for the review Pádraig,

In patch set 1, I had the db_create command override the db_auto_create option, as the user's intent in issuing a creation command is clear - they want that DB fully created.

However db_sync is slightly different, as the Essex behaviour was not to create the image* tables when applied to a fresh DB. So I think we should respect the db_auto_create setting for now.

If/when the db_auto_create defaults to False instead of true  , we could revisit and override this option if defaulted (as opposed to being explicitly set to False).

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-18 17:56:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I have to disagree.

An _explicit_ db_sync would usually mean have the db created and up to date. Whether the db_sync or glance service does the creation, doesn't really matter as the end result is the same I think?

I.E. if the db_sync does the create it should have no adverse effects, but by doing that it will all use to have
db_auto_create=False, and do the db_sync seperately,
avoiding the glance auto creation issues we've identified."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-18 19:09:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I.E. if the db_sync does the create it should have no adverse effects, but by doing that it will all use to have db_auto_create=False, and do the db_sync seperately, avoiding the glance auto creation issues we've identified.

Sorry I don't really get what you mean here about doing the db_sync separately.

The current logic in the patch is:

  # Case I
  cat foo.conf
   [DEFAULT]
   sql_connection = sqlite:///foo.sqlite
  glance-manage db_sync --config-file foo.conf
  #  => DB is fully created

  # Case II
  cat foo.conf
   [DEFAULT]
   sql_connection = sqlite:///foo.sqlite
   db_auto_create = True
  glance-manage db_sync --config-file foo.conf
  #  => DB is fully  created

  # Case III
  cat foo.conf
    [DEFAULT]
    sql_connection = sqlite:///foo.sqlite
    db_auto_create = False
  glance-manage db_sync --config-file foo.conf
  #  => revert to current db_syn behaviour 
  #     (image* tables not created)

Is it Case I that you're concerned about, or Case III?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-18 20:10:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

case III

If you think it may cause an issue to create the tables in this case too, then that's cool. I.E. if you prefer to be more conservative in this case we can put an additional patch in the distro to cater for this case.
My point is that I'm not sure we're catering for any
extra practical compatibility by being more conservative in this case.

cheers,
Pádraig."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-19 07:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-19 07:43:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Pádraig,

Well, extra patches in the distro should be avoided if possible, instead lets get the upstream version to a point that's acceptable to all.

So in patch set 4, as requested I've restored the db_auto_create override logic that I previously had in patch set 1.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-19 10:14:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Eoghan.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-21 14:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I didn't realize how messy this code was. We really need to take some time and rethink all of our peripheral db code. This is fine for now."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-21 20:59:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

A step in the right direction. I'd like to see us go ahead and rip out the code to auto-create the DB altogether but I suppose being cautious is good too."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:19:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4228/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/662/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/843/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/359/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/360/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-18 14:49:30.000000000', 'message': "Support DB auto-create suppression.

Adds a new boolean config option, db_auto_create, to allow the
DB auto-creation be suppressed on demand. This defaults to True
for now to maintain the pre-existing behaviour, but should be
changed to False before the Folsom release.

A new 'glance-manage db_create' command is added to allow the
DB be pre-created.

The @glance.tests.function.runs_sql annotation is now obsolete
as the glance-api/registry services launched by functional tests
must now all run against an on-disk sqlite instance (as opposed
to in-memory, as this makes no sense when the DB tables are
created in advance).

Change-Id: I05fc6b3ca7691dfaf00bc75a0743c921c93b9694
"}, {'created': '2012-05-18 16:35:46.000000000', 'message': "Support DB auto-create suppression.

Adds a new boolean config option, db_auto_create, to allow the
DB auto-creation be suppressed on demand. This defaults to True
for now to maintain the pre-existing behaviour, but should be
changed to False before the Folsom release.

A new 'glance-manage db_create' command is added to allow the
DB be pre-created.

The @glance.tests.function.runs_sql annotation is now obsolete
as the glance-api/registry services launched by functional tests
must now all run against an on-disk sqlite instance (as opposed
to in-memory, as this makes no sense when the DB tables are
created in advance).

Change-Id: I05fc6b3ca7691dfaf00bc75a0743c921c93b9694
"}, {'created': '2012-05-18 16:42:17.000000000', 'message': "Support DB auto-create suppression.

Adds a new boolean config option, db_auto_create, to allow the
DB auto-creation be suppressed on demand. This defaults to True
for now to maintain the pre-existing behaviour, but should be
changed to False before the Folsom release.

The 'glance-manage db_sync' command will now create the image*
tables if the DB did not previously exist.

commit_message:
Support DB auto-create suppression.

Adds a new boolean config option, db_auto_create, to allow the
DB auto-creation be suppressed on demand. This defaults to True
for now to maintain the pre-existing behaviour, but should be
changed to False before the Folsom release.

The 'glance-manage db_sync' command will now create the image*
tables if the DB did not previously exist. The db_auto_create
flag is irrelevant in that case.

The @glance.tests.function.runs_sql annotation is now obsolete
as the glance-api/registry services launched by functional tests
must now all run against an on-disk sqlite instance (as opposed
to in-memory, as this makes no sense when the DB tables are
created in advance).

Change-Id: I05fc6b3ca7691dfaf00bc75a0743c921c93b9694

commit_message:
Adds instance_utils library and initial SSH tests

* Provides an instance util class for common server queries
* Refactored the create server smoke test as an example
* Added ssh tag to tests requiring SSH to allow them to be
  skipped if needed

Change-Id: Ia34d7c75ad05f7658d1abb7bebeb1bbd271fd089

commit_message:
Fix up coverage and jenkins test running.

The docs job wasn't working because of an un-renamed file.
Coverage wasn't running in jenkins with the xml output file.
Remove the .cache.bundle support that we're moving away from.

Change-Id: I1140baa53dee8b14ac4d1f8549425a0fdd7a8425

commit_message:
Bring cincderclient up to speed with novaclient

* Implements bp/cinder python-cinder-client
* Grabs the current novaclient and builds off of it
* Tests pass
* Able to manage volumes in an Essex cloud

Change-Id: Iaadcb2dae697d0c838977f836d6b34be5bb9bc12

commit_message:
Invalidate user tokens when a user is disabled

Fixes Bug 997194

Delete valid tokens for a user when they have been disabled

Moved logic to delete tokens into update_user, as this can be called
directly form the REST API.

Also checks if a user is enabled when creating a token from another
token, this helps in cases there the backend didn't support listing of
tokens (and as a result weren't deleted)

Change-Id: Ib5ed73a7873bfa66ef31bf6d0f0322f50e677688

Thanks Mark for the review. I think I'm for refactoring the dispatch for methods to move some of the instance_uuid magic out of the AMQP layer, but I'm on the fence still about the global task tracking. I'd love to here some more opinions about that (and it doesn't have to be just Mark's either).

I have some more fixes to this patch as well, mostly related to libvirt that smokestack found."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-04-25 17:28:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks extremely useful. I think, as a first cut, it gets the job done quite well.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-25 17:29:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

Needs a libvirt fix. I'll remove the -2 after I push up a new fix."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-25 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

My view hasn't changed, but I would like to make sure any other interested parties have time to discuss this change."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-25 18:34:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So that's it? No other replies to my comments?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-25 20:03:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

So sorry, I just thought you were looking for other folks opinions rather than more of mine. 

I think you're really on to something with putting dispatch logic in the Manager.

I imagine, however, that we don't want to track tasks directly in the compute manager code. (I believe this fact, if true, is only a symptom of the problem that the compute manager is an ungodly large class, and not an indication that the code doesn't really belong at that level... nevertheless--) Perhaps we could make a decorator object (not a python decorator!) that does compute-manager appropriate task monitoring. 

class TaskTrackingComputeManager(object):

  def __init__(self, compute_manager):
    self.compute_manager = compute_manager

  def __getattr__(self, key):
    orig = getattr(self.compute_manager, key)
    return self.appropriate_wrapper_goes_here(orig)

  def appropriate_wrapper_goes_here(self, fun):
    # instance-oriented task tracking!
    pass

We could also make a more generic task tracking manager decorator if other managers need to get in on the fun but don't have any specific refinements to make. Although I suspect that the specific cases are more useful for debugging than the generic ones, so maybe we can just skip a generic implementation."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-02 16:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-02 16:42:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Here's an updated version that moves all of the tracking management to the Manager level.

It works well for XenAPI in my testing, but libvirt doesn't like getting signals in the middle of polling.

I'm still digging deeper to see what can be done for libvirt."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-03 05:50:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Looking pretty cool.  Like this version much better than what I saw when peaking back at previous patch set.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-03 16:59:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

reviewing! but in case I'm slow, removing the ol' -2 millstone ahead of time"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:14:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

can't tell if you are still work in progress or not..
+2 if you're done."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:15:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It works well for XenAPI and works well for most cases with libvirt, but I did see a hang which looks like it was the result of a bug/misfeature in libvirt. I want to investigate it further to make sure this doesn't introduce a regression when using libvirt."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:20:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Looks great! I like the rpc/service/manager relationship refactoring here too.

I'll hold off a bit on approval until I get the green light from you on libvirt issues."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-08 11:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this
