subject: Fix flavor listing filtered be minimum
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hmm, I'm not sure this really fixes things in a good future-proof way. I think I'd almost prefer to grab all the flavors in setUpClass, make a few lists of flavor dicts, ordered in various ways, and then use known IDs of the flavor with minRam/maxRam filters...

So, in the setUpclass method, we'd grab the flavors, then sort the dicts by ram and store the first flavor ID and the amount of ram for the flavor in cls.flavor_with_least_ram. Then in the tests for filtering on min_ram, we use that information in our API calls..."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:45:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If I understand you correctly, you're asking to do the same thing that has been done, in a slightly different manner.

The problem is that it fails if for example all the flavor has the same RAM amount… I really think this is the right change since it really tastes correctly the behaviour in ALL cases.

Eventually, I'd accept to add one more check, like this:

resp, filtered_flavors = self.client.list_flavors(params)
self.assertNotIn(flavor_id, [f['id'] for f in filtered_flavors])
if
self.assertGreaterEqual(set([f['id'] for f in flavors[1:]]), set([f['id'] for f in filtered_flavors]))"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Argh, I meant:

resp, filtered_flavors = self.client.list_flavors(params)

self.assertNotIn(flavor_id, [f['id'] for f in filtered_flavors])

self.assertGreaterEqual(set([f['id'] for f in flavors[1:]]), set([f['id'] for f in filtered_flavors]))"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-04-19 09:27:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-26 04:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Still one issue with this set of changes. See inline comments."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-05-02 13:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:38:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Fix flavor listing filtered be minimum

We cannot assume that the ram or disk size of flavors[1] will be strictly
greater than the one of flavors[0].

Instead, let's add 1 to flavors[0] and make sure that flavors[0] is not
returned in the list.

Also, the assertion format is changed to be more readable when the test
fail.

This fixes bug #979728

Change-Id: I542ea4c393c0ad3b33e2e453975fbfcaf643aafb
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
fix action to instance after compute restart , bug 967989
1. it should only restart the instances whose state is running
2. change flag name
start_guests_on_host_boot -> restart_guests_on_host_boot
resume_guests_state_on_host_boot -> start_guests_on_host_boot
3. ensure_filtering_rules_for_instance for all running instances

Change-Id: I654765c4b0a7ae42f2e34edf0aebda8d4e1c40b8

subject: Verbose should not enable debug level logging
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-27 15:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm a little uncomfortable with making WARNING the default logging level especially since INFO was the default before this patch. Nova has way too much useful information at INFO and should probably be the default still.

How about we remove --verbose and replace it with --quiet which then sets the logging level to WARNING?"}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2012-04-27 15:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yup, I am fine with making that change.  We'll default to loggging.INFO and make --quiet logging.WARNING"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:24:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Just wanted to make sure you saw the smokestack note about unit test issues."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-11 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Verbose should not enable debug level logging

Fixes bug 989269

Currently setting --verbose in nova.conf will still allow DEBUG level
message to be logged to python logger object. The issue is nova/log.py
check for --debug OR --verbose for setting logging.DEBUG

Change-Id: Ic815fea0ac2cb2739a14466afd0e6bee9c681b19
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>

[{'created': '2012-05-02 06:20:19.000000000', 'message': "Fixed errors in while deleting nova keypairs

Description: nova keypait-delete <keypair_name> command is not able
             to delete the keypair_name which are having special
             characters like ('.','/','#').so made some changes in
             keypairs.py file create() method.while creating only
             doesn't allow those special characters as keypair_names.

Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I96c789475abd516a9b8a5f6c29d3d2cad037dfa3
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed errors in while deleting nova keypairs

Description: nova keypait-delete <keypair_name> command is not able
             to delete the keypair_name which are having special
             characters like ('.','/','#').so made some changes in
             keypairs.py file create() method.while creating only
             doesn't allow those special characters as keypair_names.

Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I96c789475abd516a9b8a5f6c29d3d2cad037dfa3

subject: SwiftException base class for all swift exceptions.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3076, 'date': '2012-05-03 21:12:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems like a good idea to me.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What's the point of this change?

Why were those method redefined in SwiftException?  Exception has methods like that already.  SwiftException could just have a 'pass' body."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:54:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The main reason of this exception is to have base exception class with which we can filter only Swift exceptions and don't have dependency on changes of python Exception class (such as message attribute in Exception class).

python 2.6:
>>> e = Exception('Exception')
>>> e.message
__main__:1: DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6
'Exception'

python 2.7:
>>> e = Exception('Exception')
>>> e.message
'Exception'

But if is not important I will replace SwiftException code with pass."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-10 23:17:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think the base SwiftException is a fine idea, but I think the message part should be dropped as it's not something Python really wants in use anymore. See the Retracted Ideas section at http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/#retracted-ideas"}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-11 00:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-11 00:25:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-11 01:59:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Sure.  Why not?  I'll be watching to see when the first code change actually starts using this.  = )"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-11 02:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/98/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/98/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/213/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-11 02:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
SwiftException base class for all swift exceptions.

Also add new exception class SwiftConfigurationError,
that can't be used to indicate that swift parameters
in swift conf files are not correct.

Change-Id: I39bff9068a19c8e1c1b4aac38cb756c5e46d75e6

commit_message:
Use ConfigOpts.find_file() to find paste config

Use cfg's new helper method to find the paste deploy config file. The
basic behavior is "look alongside the config file" with a fall back to
the standard default config paths.

Change-Id: If7a9ac1d456f372e3f5f6c78e237a7b099d1a30e

[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-24 18:30:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

First of all, I'll point out that the way you submitted this patch, it really looked like you were simply resubmitting this so as to evade my -2.  I'm sure you didn't intend for it to look that way, but it did.

Second, there are some serious stylistic errors in your updated setup.py.  You have read HACKING.rst, yes?  Several of the errors I see appear to violate that document.

Third, I don't believe that you have properly integrated with openstack-common.  I believe there is a configuration file you will need to update in order to properly pull in openstack-common's setup.py utilities.  I will ask Jason Kölker to take a look at this patch and provide you some guidance on the proper use of openstack-common.

Fourth, and most minor: It appears an extraneous letter 'a' has appeared in your commit message; I'd appreciate it if you could clean that up."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-04-25 16:43:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Generate a Changelog for Nova

Ubuntu uses a tarball to generate packages for Nova and
other openstack projects. This allows the user to find out
what is included in the tarball.

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

Change-Id: I0291e19eee1ff2c5fc98b499571b2563841c6076

accepted here. It however works.

Patch set 3: Now using netaddr library(used also by nova),
which provides support for validation of IP addresses.
Using this library, now the IPField can support more
ways to enter an IP - like short versions:
10/8 - for all 10.xxx.xxx.xxx
192.168/16 - for all 192.168.xxx.xxx

Regarding IPy library - it performs some strict
subnet validation, which will not accept cidr like this:
192.168.1.1/20
because the only mask that matches this IP is 32.
IPy doesn't allow broader masks. But my assumption is
that the operators should take the responsibility for
the data they enter. At least this CIDR is valid after all.

Change-Id: Ie497fe65fde3af25a18109a182ab78255ad7ec60

commit_message:
Implementation of blueprint ip-validation

First draft. Added a forms.Field wrapper for IPAddress.
Implemented IPv4 and IPv6 checks, subnet mask range,
optional mask range limitation.

As far as I see now, there is only 1 place in Dashboard
to accept IP fields as input - the Security rules.
I've tried to input IPv6 rule and it was accepted.
The previous version of the code doesn't accept
IPv6, only IPv4. I am not sure if IPv6 should be
accepted here. It however works.

Patch set 3: Now using netaddr library(used also by nova),
which provides support for validation of IP addresses.
Using this library, now the IPField can support more
ways to enter an IP - like short versions:
10/8 - for all 10.xxx.xxx.xxx
192.168/16 - for all 192.168.xxx.xxx

Regarding IPy library - it performs some strict
subnet validation, which will not accept cidr like this:
192.168.1.1/20
because the only mask that matches this IP is 32.
IPy doesn't allow broader masks. But my assumption is
that the operators should take the responsibility for
the data they enter. At least this CIDR is valid after all.

Change-Id: Ie497fe65fde3af25a18109a182ab78255ad7ec60

[{'created': '2012-05-10 21:19:24.000000000', 'message': "Fix XenServer windows agent issue

Windows agent requires an argument of either 'agent' or 'xentools' to
the 'version' command.  All we care about is 'agent', so add it.  The
unix agent happily ignores the arg.

Fixes bug 997805

Change-Id: Ic369c8a2850173057da9d3175a02b5864d7a6514
"}]
commit_message:
Fix XenServer windows agent issue

Windows agent requires an argument of either 'agent' or 'xentools' to
the 'version' command.  All we care about is 'agent', so add it.  The
unix agent happily ignores the arg.

Fixes bug 997805

Change-Id: Ic369c8a2850173057da9d3175a02b5864d7a6514

commit_message:
Force prettytable==0.5

prettytable 0.6 was released recently and removed the printt() method.
All non-pinned prettytable projects (all of them) are now broken.  This
forces a pre-loaded prettytable 0.5 package in order to allow the real
fix (removing printt() calls) to proceed.

Change-Id: Iacf24b8474f12b28090329496720767281181d7e

commit_message:
Use ConfigOpts.find_file() to locate policy.json

Use cfg's new helper method to find policy config file. The basic
behavior is "look alongside the config file" with a fall back to
the standard default config paths.

Change-Id: I763097107c53fc9b7d4e783ee92bf16989d92cff

subject: Added periodic_task to cleanup orphaned volumes.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-05-10 17:38:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Seems like a good idea, I'm a little concerned about it being an automatic process.  I'll let others provide input on this, but perhaps an API call thereby making it a manual process that can be run when desired?"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-05-10 17:42:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

BTW if https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7131/ ever lands you'll need to make some changes (instance_id -> instance_uuid) as the instance_id and instance relationship is dropped from volumes table."}, {'account_id': 25, 'date': '2012-05-10 18:33:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Don't like the idea of this being an automatic process, if users want to pay us to keep old volumes, who are we to argue?

It is entirely possible to implement all of this via the existing apis as an external daemon, do we really want it in core?"}, {'account_id': 1613, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Volume in Nova can exist independent of an instance. So closing this one.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-10 17:21:18.000000000', 'message': 'Added periodic_task to cleanup orphaned volumes.

Finds all volumes that are not associated to any instances and
deletes them.
The task runs every 60 ticks by default, and cleans up volumes
that have been orphaned for more than a week.

Change-Id: I519fc3791a651cc4483a6ef0b1c899114ca7df16
'}]
commit_message:
Added periodic_task to cleanup orphaned volumes.

Finds all volumes that are not associated to any instances and
deletes them.
The task runs every 60 ticks by default, and cleans up volumes
that have been orphaned for more than a week.

Change-Id: I519fc3791a651cc4483a6ef0b1c899114ca7df16

subject: bug 985905: multi_host flag cunfusing settings
messages:
[{'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-20 00:15:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I would prefer to continue to convert settings to use the trueorfalse function for setting default values.  See OFFLINE for an example.  This will maintain backwards compatibility with the current localrc files in use.

This allows use of '0 no false False FALSE' for False and '1 yes true True TRUE' for True.  All tests can then be done only for 'False' or 'True'."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-20 18:36:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-20 18:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Cheers,
Armando'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-20 18:51:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

./exercises/floating_ips.sh:MULTI_HOST=${MULTI_HOST:-0}
./exercises/floating_ips.sh:if [ "$MULTI_HOST" = "0" ]; then
./exercises/quantum.sh:    MULTI_HOST=${MULTI_HOST:-0}
./exercises/quantum.sh:    if [ "$MULTI_HOST" = "0" ]; 

what do you think?

commit_message:
Fixed secgroup-add-rule

secgroup-add-rule was being done to "default" group when it should have been
done to "openpub" group.

Other changes:
 * Mac OS -> Mac OS X
 * Added a <link> to trystack.org
 * Random line wrap changes due to editing with Oxygen

Change-Id: I4138b7799eff62a1df24b1155c9d496c35a141a0

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-10 00:44:37.000000000', 'message': 'Allow proper log output during test runs.

This involved a huge amount of cleanup to existing code
in order to make sure that existing failures were properly
fixed or silenced when intentional.

Additionally, this introduces a set of pre-built exception
instances for test purposes which are marked with the
"silence_logging" attribute to denote expected failures which
should not be logged in test output.

commit_message:
Allow proper log output during test runs.

This involved a huge amount of cleanup to existing code
in order to make sure that existing failures were properly
fixed or silenced when intentional.

Additionally, this introduces a set of pre-built exception
instances for test purposes which are marked with the
"silence_logging" attribute to denote expected failures which
should not be logged in test output.

Change-Id: I6b420382dcdc5792c7be4d727853f438154c641e

commit_message:
More identity client config

* move auth option checking back to OpenStackShell() to keep the shell-level
  interaction at that level; add checking for token flow options

* make identity.client.make_client() configure keystoneclient.v2_0.Client()
  properly for both password flow and token flow auth

* eliminated ClientManager.init_token(), set _service_catalog in __init__()

* compute client handles token flow

Change-Id: I42481b5424489387798c4ec6d3e2a723ab1e6067

commit_message:
Removed ambiguity about when to sync the nova db.

The documentation as written was ambiguous about whether the nova-manage
sync_db command should be run after the database is created. Reworded to
try to make this less ambiguity.

Also removed some text about setting up the database, since the database
setup has already been described in the preceding section.

Change-Id: I8a23c0118965cfaa6141d1230a890777770d86ff

commit_message:
Speed up swift-get-nodes by 2x.

It was loading the ring off disk once to print the primary nodes, and
then loading the whole thing off disk again to print the handoff
nodes. Changed it to only load the ring off disk once.

Change-Id: I6f4cd0af9762e1e69660c3eb20586590b5339e5f

commit_message:
Implement unit_test config to disable syslog.

bug 701248
bug 819303

This change makes syslog optional, by providing a unit test
config with the ability to cause test/unit/__init__.py to
replace SysLogHandler with a fake logging class. The
default behavior is unchanged.

FakeLogger now inherits directly from Handler and mocks out
its API - this was a backward-compatibility issue.

Change-Id: I653dec148c4f6cf81759de03964c6a3290c1a290

subject: As-unique-as-possible partition replica placement.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 20:10:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

When I was dreaming about this (or were they nightmares?) I wondered how to get replication to work properly.

I know there are cases where replication tries to be generic, but I'm not sure it succeeds as I don't think we tested for it.

For example, with 3 replicas, node A contacts B and C where B and C have always been different servers.

With this, B and C could not only be on the same server, but could even be on the same device, meaning you really have fewer replicas than the count of nodes from ring.get_nodes, etc.

As a for instance, have you tested that all three replication types work correctly with high replica collisions? Making sure they don't replicate (rsync, etc) with the exact same on-disk items?

Great work on this and I hope to have the brain power and time to review it soon."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-26 21:33:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

>I know there are cases where replication tries to be generic, but I'm not sure it succeeds as I don't think we tested for it.
> For example, with 3 replicas, node A contacts B and C where B and C have always been different servers.

Even without this change, replication works intra-server. I routinely run a 2-server, 6-disk cluster for development where the zone layout looks like this:

3 replicas
z1: box1/sdb, box1/sdc
z2: box2/sdb, box2/sdc
z3: box1/sdd, box2/sdd

Replication has always worked just fine for me in that case.

I've also taken a 3-disk SAIO box with data in it, rm'ed some files in /srv/node/d2, and watched the replicators put them back, so I have high confidence that intra-server replication to a different device works.

> With this, B and C could not only be on the same server, but could even be on the same device, meaning you really have fewer replicas than the count of nodes from ring.get_nodes, etc.
> As a for instance, have you tested that all three replication types work correctly with high replica collisions? Making sure they don't replicate (rsync, etc) with the exact same on-disk items?

I believe (though I could be wrong) that by deduplicating the nodes that come out of ring.get_[part_]nodes, a replicator will never find itself in a situation where it has two references to the same device, and so it won't get the opportunity to trip over itself in that manner. If you have 3 replicas and only 2 devices, the replicator will only get back 2 nodes from ring.get_nodes, and so it'll behave as though there are only 2 replicas.

That's why I took the references to ring.replica_count out of the proxy and the replicators. It seemed to me like the cleanest way to implement.

> Great work on this and I hope to have the brain power and time to review it soon.

Thanks! If you have more questions or concerns, you can also sometimes find me on IRC in #openstack-dev as torgomatic."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 22:33:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Very cool. I'm glad you've tested on that, as I haven't. What you say makes perfect sense, I just wasn't sure you had thought on that. :)

Will do review soon. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-27 03:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I did some timing tests with this (memory usage looks good, as does final balance):

Create brand new ring, 5 zones, 36 servers per zone, 24 drives per server, then rebalance:
Old way: 42s
New way: 755s (12m35s)

Add one more zone to ring, 36 servers in zone, 24 drives per server, then rebalance:
Old way: 14s
New way: 164s (2m44s)

Now, to counter this (which really isn't that bad anyway, not like we make rings 100 times a day or anything) just adding the initial nodes (no rebalance yet) takes 1558s (25m58s) and adding the new zone's nodes takes 460s (7m40s).

So speeding up the addition of many nodes at once would more than make up for the slower algorithm. We've been meaning to make an "add nodes via csv file" type feature for a long while now, but just haven't got to it yet. The majority of the add-nodes time is spent starting python, loading the builder, and finally writing the new builder, over and over. Anyway, such a feature is a whole other patch, so ignore that for now. :)

I mostly just wanted to post this up to say I've tested the timing and it seems "fast enough" and in case you had any ideas for speeding it up before it hits master.

That's all the time I have for tonight; I'll check out the code itself more closely another night.

-----

As an aside, brimring, which does a similar "highest tier possible separation", takes 269s (4m29s) on the initial test and then gobbles up all memory and grinds to a halt on the add zone test (bah, stupid computers ;). So while brimring is ahead on the initial creation, it can't realistically do the second (gotta work on that one day). I once thought about fitting Swift with a Brim Ring but you can imagine the backwards compatibility fun that'd bring (besides the fact it isn't trustworthy yet).'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-27 22:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-27 22:19:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I found a decent spot to optimize in there. When a device gets a partition, it used to be popped out of the devices array, then a binary-search-and-insert was done to put it back at its new spot. I had replaced that with a plain .sort() and made a note to go back and try out a binary-search-and-insert.

Turns out that making a note doesn't actually make the code fast. :) I went back and did it in patch set 2, and managed to cut down the time for a rebalance by 2/3.

Using a similar setup to yours (5 zones, 36 machines, etc.), I got the following on my machine:

Without this change: 53 s
Patch set 1: 1090 s
Patch set 2: 344 s

So it still takes around 6x what the old builder did, but I was able to knock that down from 20x.

I also experimented with changing the representation of tiers from tuples to pipe-delimited strings, but the results were inconclusive, so I didn't commit that.

Unless you disagree, I'm going to call it fast enough for now, though I'll probably end up trying to optimize things further later on. Rackspace may not rebalance rings hundreds of times a day, but SwiftStack sure does. :)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-29 16:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-01 00:51:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Looking great; just one inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-01 03:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Response inline.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-01 13:00:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:47:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Patch set 4 fixes two problems: 

Problem 1:
in builder.py line 562, we update dev['parts'] and dev['parts_wanted'],

then:

in builder.py line 569, we look in tier2sort_key[tier] for dev's old ['sort_key']. Should you have multiple devices with the same parts_wanted *and* they happen to get the same random 16-bit integer in their sort keys *and* you get unlucky in which one is at the index that bisect_left returns, the devs in tier2dev[dev] could get out of order.

The fix is just to add dev['id'] as a fallback tiebreaker in the sort key, which you can see in _sort_key_for().

Problem 2: merge conflicts with d2d0922. Easy fixes."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-08 04:42:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Samuel,

I'm part way through reviewing this and have some comments/questions.

1)  RingBuilder._insert_dev_sorted() isn't used any more and should be removed.

2)  I know you didn't do this, but in RingBuilder._sort_key_for(), why is self.parts added to parts wanted to make the first section of the key?  I can't figure out why that happens.  Seems like things should work without that.  If you agree, could you remove that if you submit another patch?

3)  In RingBuilder._gather_reassign_parts(), in the second chunk of code, it seems like too many devices can be assigned to spread_out_parts.  If a device's tier has more than max allowed replicas, the device is assigned to spread_out_parts.  However, the replicas_at_tier is not recalculated after the device is removed.  So, for example, if 2 of the 3 replicas are on 2 devices that share a tier that can have at most 1 replica, seems like both devices would be moved when only one needs to be moved.

This is the first time I've looked at the ring builder code.  So, I might be completely making up 3).  Let me know what you think.  = )"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> 1) RingBuilder._insert_dev_sorted() isn't used any more and should be removed.

Done.

> 2) I know you didn't do this, but in RingBuilder._sort_key_for(), why is self.parts added to parts wanted to make the first section of the key? I can't figure out why that happens. Seems like things should work without that. If you agree, could you remove that if you submit another patch?

A device's parts_wanted can be negative (consider a ring that just had some devices added; the existing devices will want to shed partitions), and a negative number doesn't fit into the format "%08x" very well. To make that number positive, we add self.parts since no device's parts_wanted can be less than -(self.parts).

...or it couldn't until this patch. Since multiple replicas can now cram onto a single device, the lower bound on parts_wanted is now -(self.replicas * self.parts), so the width of this field has to be increased.

Actually, I think there's a longstanding bug here for really large rings. A ring with 2^32 partitions (the maximum) would add 2^32 + parts_wanted, and that would overflow the format %08x for any nonnegative parts_wanted, and that would screw up the sort order.

In any case, you've found a bug (hooray!), the solution to which is to make the field wider. Done.

> 3) In RingBuilder._gather_reassign_parts(), in the second chunk of code, it seems like too many devices can be assigned to spread_out_parts. If a device's tier has more than max allowed replicas, the device is assigned to spread_out_parts. However, the replicas_at_tier is not recalculated after the device is removed. So, for example, if 2 of the 3 replicas are on 2 devices that share a tier that can have at most 1 replica, seems like both devices would be moved when only one needs to be moved.

Yep, that's exactly what happens. Fixed (including unit test).'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-09 00:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Sam, I've added a bunch of commentary you might consider 'patch -p1 < diff' applying to this:

http://paste.openstack.org/raw/16352/

I also made some minor changes here and there for clarity and where I think there might've been a bug. However, the bug I think I found is causing tests to fail so I'm pretty sure I'm confused still. :)

In _gather_reassign_parts, in the section that gathers parts to reassign based on they're not being "spread out" enough, I changed it to only move at most one replica for a partition (including if it had been moved due to a removed device earlier). Can you check that out and let me know what I'm doing wrong, or if that's more correct and the tests just need updating?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-09 18:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-09 18:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Love the explanatory comments; happy to add them in.

> In _gather_reassign_parts, in the section that gathers parts to reassign based on they're not being "spread out" enough, I changed it to only move at most one replica for a partition (including if it had been moved due to a removed device earlier). Can you check that out and let me know what I'm doing wrong, or if that's more correct and the tests just need updating?

I went back and forth on that decision a few times.

On the one hand, if I'm a cluster operator with a small cluster, say 2 nodes in 1 zone, and then I expand my cluster to 8 nodes in 4 zones, I'd expect my replicas to spread out across my zones right away.

On the other hand, it's a good idea to only intentionally move 1 replica at a time. It keeps network traffic down and (in the common 3-replica case) it ensures data availability in case of a failure of another replica.

So, in this patch set, I've gone with your idea of respecting min_part_hours for moving not-spread-out-enough replicas. I've also added a couple of unit tests that zero in on that behavior.

As to why that patch caused test failures: some partition replicas could get gathered up multiple times, which would break the double-accounting check in RingBuilder.validate(). Basically, the spread-out-partitions code needed to skip over partitions in removed_dev_parts since they're already on the list of stuff to move. Likewise, the gather-overweight-partitions code needed to skip over partitions in removed_dev_parts (which it was doing already) and in spread_out_parts (which it was not). Fixed.


One other noteworthy change in the latest patch set: I removed the tier checking in RingBuilder.validate(), as it was broken sometimes. In particular, if you had some close-together replicas, and then you added some devices so things could spread out *but* you did not rebalance yet, then the new validate() would complain. That seemed like undesirable behavior to me, so I took that stuff out. Also, the ring wasn't exactly broken in that case, just suboptimal, so having validate() fail seemed like overkill.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-09 19:00:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Very cool. I'll start looking at this again now and hopefully the other Greg (Lange) can too so we can get this done. :)"}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-09 22:08:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm done looking at everything and I found only one small problem.

In swift/common/ring/builder.py, the first arg to the function find_home_for_replica() isn't actually used by that function (except to recursively pass to itself).  So, it can be removed.

Otherwise, this change looks good as far as I can tell."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-09 22:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-09 23:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:03:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/94/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/94/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/209/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-26 18:33:26.000000000', 'message': "As-unique-as-possible partition replica placement.

This commit introduces a new algorithm for assigning partition
replicas to devices. Basically, the ring builder organizes the devices
into tiers (first zone, then IP/port, then device ID). When placing a
replica, the ring builder looks for the emptiest device (biggest
parts_wanted) in the furthest-away tier.

In the case where zone-count >= replica-count, the new algorithm will
give the same results as the one it replaces. Thus, no migration is
needed.

In the case where zone-count < replica-count, the new algorithm
behaves differently from the old algorithm. The new algorithm will
distribute things evenly at each tier so that the replication is as
high-quality as possible, given the circumstances. The old algorithm
would just crash, so again, no migration is needed.

Handoffs have also been updated to use the new algorithm. When
generating handoff nodes, first the ring looks for nodes in other
zones, then other ips/ports, then any other drive. The first handoff
nodes (the ones in other zones) will be the same as before; this
commit just extends the list of handoff nodes.

The proxy server and replicators have been altered to avoid looking at
the ring's replica count directly. Previously, with a replica count of
C, RingData.get_nodes() and RingData.get_part_nodes() would return
lists of length C, so some other code used the replica count when it
needed the number of nodes. If two of a partition's replicas are on
the same device (e.g. with 3 replicas, 2 devices), then that
assumption is no longer true. Fortunately, all the proxy server and
replicators really needed was the number of nodes returned, which they
already had. (Bonus: now the only code that mentions replica_count
directly is in the ring and the ring builder.)

Change-Id: Iba2929edfc6ece89791890d0635d4763d821a3aa

commit_message:
As-unique-as-possible partition replica placement.

This commit introduces a new algorithm for assigning partition
replicas to devices. Basically, the ring builder organizes the devices
into tiers (first zone, then IP/port, then device ID). When placing a
replica, the ring builder looks for the emptiest device (biggest
parts_wanted) in the furthest-away tier.

In the case where zone-count >= replica-count, the new algorithm will
give the same results as the one it replaces. Thus, no migration is
needed.

In the case where zone-count < replica-count, the new algorithm
behaves differently from the old algorithm. The new algorithm will
distribute things evenly at each tier so that the replication is as
high-quality as possible, given the circumstances. The old algorithm
would just crash, so again, no migration is needed.

Handoffs have also been updated to use the new algorithm. When
generating handoff nodes, first the ring looks for nodes in other
zones, then other ips/ports, then any other drive. The first handoff
nodes (the ones in other zones) will be the same as before; this
commit just extends the list of handoff nodes.

The proxy server and replicators have been altered to avoid looking at
the ring's replica count directly. Previously, with a replica count of
C, RingData.get_nodes() and RingData.get_part_nodes() would return
lists of length C, so some other code used the replica count when it
needed the number of nodes. If two of a partition's replicas are on
the same device (e.g. with 3 replicas, 2 devices), then that
assumption is no longer true. Fortunately, all the proxy server and
replicators really needed was the number of nodes returned, which they
already had. (Bonus: now the only code that mentions replica_count
directly is in the ring and the ring builder.)

Change-Id: Iba2929edfc6ece89791890d0635d4763d821a3aa

subject: API does need new image_ref on rebuild immediately.
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-10 01:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Chris. This version seems to support both the old use case where API users can see the updated image_ref immediately... but also allows you to send the proper notification as well.

Looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-10 14:50:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I can't help but feel that these usage notifications are pretty opinionated and we should really rip them out into a separate place.

But I think this is the right way to interact with the database (go ahead and update so that the api feels fast, but then don't rely on the database for message passing). So I think this is a good change regardless of its origins."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Change-Id: I8cf6a8759e8fe605bb023048a320b15eee3bcd80

commit_message:
API does need new image_ref on rebuild immediately.

This restores the DB update for image_ref immediately on rebuild, but
passes the old image_ref to the manager for use with instance.exists
notification.

Fixes the fix for bug 997245

Change-Id: I8cf6a8759e8fe605bb023048a320b15eee3bcd80

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:18:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
cfg: automatically create option groups

Implements blueprint cfg-auto-create-groups

Remove the restriction that groups must be explicitly created. Often
you only need a group to have a name (not e.g. a title or help string)
so we can easily just auto-create groups for that case.

Change-Id: I150ab3900e3aad0068b93487c8d396d21d26cfea

Implements blueprint cfg-required-options

Add a 'required' flag to option schemas:

  StrOpt('foo', required=True)

which causes a RequiredOptError exception to be raised if the

a config file.

"}]
commit_message:
cfg: allow options to be marked as required

Implements blueprint cfg-required-options

Add a 'required' flag to option schemas:

  StrOpt('foo', required=True)

which causes a RequiredOptError exception to be raised if the
user fails to supply a value for the option on the CLI or in
a config file.

Change-Id: Ied7bb25f0c1582c4991d0f212f4871b9358b73fb

commit_message:
XenServer install: use MGT network for services

The new install was using the PUB network for OpenStack
services. Changing this to be the MGT network, so that the
Xen host need not be on the public network.

Change-Id: Id9590693dc979ddb431bad96d1aa863f38de7521

What makes you think that a server has to be in suspended state for it to be resized? Is this mentioned somewhere in the api? I could see adding support for resizing while suspended perhaps, but I don't know why we would remove support for resizing an active server."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-04-25 17:30:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Resizing ACTIVE instances is completely intentional, and functional. The instance going to ERROR after you resized it in an ACTIVE state is a wholly separate (and yet unidentified) bug. You might want to do some more digging, but it's definitely possible to resize active instances."}, {'account_id': 2992, 'date': '2012-04-26 05:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-10 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'}]
commit_message:
Instance in state "error" after resize is solved

Fixes bug 907921

Resize works when the instance in the SUSPENDED state,
and it throws an exception if instance is in ACTIVE state.

In nova.conf file, add this flag --allow_resize_to_same_host=true

Change-Id: I5779470e34dcd59e250f627b9acb6bc36d33b6c5

(1 inline comment)

great!  welcome to the team :)'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi,
The change looks good.

I have one comment that is not related to the scope of the fix, but it would be nice to add if possible.

If the database service is down then the following error occurs:

[f17-dev@localhost client]$ quantum list_nets default
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/cli_lib.py", line 237, in list_nets_v11
    res = client.list_networks(**filters)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 145, in with_params
    ret = self.function(instance, *args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 522, in list_networks
    return self.get(self.networks_path, params=filters)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 379, in get
    headers=headers, params=params)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 364, in retry_request
    headers=headers, params=params)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 305, in do_request
    self._handle_fault_response(status_code, data)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 228, in _handle_fault_response
    EXCEPTION_HANDLERS[self.version](status_code, des_error_body)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/quantum/client/__init__.py", line 113, in exception_handler_v11
    ex = quantum_errors[error_type](message=error_message)
KeyError: u'QuantumServiceFault'
[f17-dev@localhost client]$ 


Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Looks good.  Comments are suggestion only, except for the monkeypatching."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4193, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4193, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4193, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ISTM that we just need to teach the client about 'QuantumServiceFault' exceptions (i.e. add that to quantum_errors in exception_handler_v1[01], mapping to an exception class, maybe an InternalServerError or something).

I'd be happy to do that myself if somebody can confirm that's what should be done.

Also, I'd like to amend this patch to include intructions to run a single testcase/testmethod plus making run_tests.py executable. Would that be ok or should I propose another patch for review?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/303/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The code looks good, but the TESTING doc needs a bit more work."}, {'account_id': 4193, 'date': '2012-05-10 05:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

commit_message:
Change Resource.__call__() to not leak internal errors.

That method now catches any non-expected errors raised by the controller's
action method and turn them into an HTTPServerError. Fixes bug 980033.

Change-Id: I7f71c029fae0e27a799f11de0802bde1003683e2

commit_message:
fix bug 977007,make nova create correct size of qcow2 disk file.

when use live block migration,ephemeral disks with qcow2 format
should be created in the destination with the same virtual size
as before.

commit_message:
Fixes to the user form, UI behaviors, and tests.

The message you got upon successful user update
was misleading as it told you all of the fields
were updated, even if no changes were made to
those fields.

Also there was an issue where in this user edit
form, where if can_edit_user was False in the
local_settings file, you could not change the
default project for a user.

Changed the stubbing behavior for tests as well
to allow the use of a decorator to stub your tests
using Mox instead of having to clutter up the
actual test with repetitive Mox stubs.

Fixes Bug #993572

Change-Id: Iaebd6525bb4509a2ec6b350df432f4f60dd35114

Updates the XenServer vmops.py _shutdown function so that it
avoids calling get_info/_get_vm_opaque_ref with the instance name.
Since _shutdown already has the vm_ref there is no need to make
this call.

This fixes an issue where 'RESIZE' was broken when resizing to

Fixes LP Bug #997313.

Change-Id: Ic5a1a0f92df9a2b809aef20a250843bf48402d75
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid unnecessary inst lookup in vmops _shutdown.

Updates the XenServer vmops.py _shutdown function so that it
avoids calling get_info/_get_vm_opaque_ref with the instance name.
Since _shutdown already has the vm_ref there is no need to make
this call.

This fixes an issue where 'RESIZE' was broken when resizing to
the same host.

Fixes LP Bug #997313.

Change-Id: Ic5a1a0f92df9a2b809aef20a250843bf48402d75

[{'created': '2012-05-09 19:23:25.000000000', 'message': "Defer image_ref update to manager on rebuild

We shouldn't update the DB and use it for passing the new image_ref for
a rebuild.  This causes a usage exists notification for the new image
instead of the old... and technically the new image is not accurate
until we shutdown the old instance and try building the new one..

Fixes bug 997245

Change-Id: Ia4bd4b8af90080a11875d9ee56661286bc3f5593
"}]
commit_message:
Defer image_ref update to manager on rebuild

We shouldn't update the DB and use it for passing the new image_ref for
a rebuild.  This causes a usage exists notification for the new image
instead of the old... and technically the new image is not accurate
until we shutdown the old instance and try building the new one..

Fixes bug 997245

Change-Id: Ia4bd4b8af90080a11875d9ee56661286bc3f5593

commit_message:
Sync to newer openstack.common.cfg

Changes since last sync are:

 * New ConfigOpts.find_file() for locating conf files
 * Support for directory source of config files
 * Provide file extension when when looking for files
 * Some refactoring of the cfg cache
 * Add caching to openstack.common.cfg

Change-Id: I5fd483b8d1a6e83f7237507132009d31dd8bcb77

commit_message:
removed cname lookup middleware

The code has moved to https://github.com/notmyname/swift-cnamelookup.

For current users of cname lookup, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the cname lookup conf section's
to:

[filter:cname_lookup]
use = egg:swift_cnamelookup#swift_cnamelookup

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: If622486ddb04a53251244c9840aa3cfe72168fc5

commit_message:
Pulled out Rate Limit middleware

Rate Limit middleware is now at
http://dpgoetz.github.com/swift-ratelimit/

For current users of Rate Limit, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the ratelimit conf section to:

[filter:ratelimit]
use = egg:swiftratelimit#middleware

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: I2ab774e9cee9fba4103c1be4bea6d52d1adb29f7

commit_message:
removed domain remap middleware

The code has moved to https://github.com/notmyname/swift-domainremap.

For current users of domain remap, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the domain remap conf section's
to:

[filter:domain_remap]
use = egg:swift_domainremap#swift_domainremap

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: I710caf9b991f9d37df36b826ae4338086d0ec36d
